Catoni-Style Change Point Detection for Regret Minimization in Non-Stationary Heavy-Tailed Bandits

Gianmarco Genalti
Politecnico di Milano
&Sujay Bhatt
JPMorgan AI Research
Nicola Gatti
Politecnico di Milano
&Alberto Maria Metelli
Politecnico di Milano
Abstract

Regret minimization in stochastic non-stationary bandits gained popularity over the last decade, as it can model a broad class of real-world problems, from advertising to recommendation systems. Existing literature relies on various assumptions about the reward-generating process, such as Bernoulli or subgaussian rewards. However, in settings such as finance and telecommunications, heavy-tailed distributions naturally arise. In this work, we tackle the heavy-tailed piecewise-stationary bandit problem. Heavy-tailed bandits, introduced by bubeck2013bandits, , operate on the minimal assumption that the finite absolute centered moments of maximum order 1+Ïµ1italic-Ïµ1+\epsilon1 + italic_Ïµ are uniformly bounded by a constant v<+âˆğ‘£v<+\inftyitalic_v < + âˆ, for some Ïµâˆˆ(0,1]italic-Ïµ01\epsilon\in(0,1]italic_Ïµ âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ]. We focus on the most popular non-stationary bandit setting, i.e., the piecewise-stationary setting, in which the mean of reward-generating distributions may change at unknown time steps. We provide a novel Catoni-style change-point detection strategy tailored for heavy-tailed distributions that relies on recent advancements in the theory of sequential estimation, which is of independent interest. We introduce Robust-CPD-UCB, which combines this change-point detection strategy with optimistic algorithms for bandits, providing its regret upper bound and an impossibility result on the minimum attainable regret for any policy. Finally, we validate our approach through numerical experiments on synthetic and real-world datasets.

1 Introduction

In a Multi-Armed Bandit (MAB, for short, lattimore2020bandit, ), a decision-maker (also called learner) is faced with a sequence of repeated decisions among a fixed number of options (or actions or arms), observing a reward drawn from a probability distribution after each decision. MABs gained popularity over the last two decades, as they allow for strong theoretical guarantees over algorithmsâ€™ performance while maintaining the modelâ€™s generality. However, the most traditional MAB model relies on demanding assumptions that are rarely met in the real world. The majority of the research effort in the MAB literature focused on progressively overcoming these limitations to cover richer scenarios. Examples include non-stationary (besbes2014stochastic, ), linear (abbasi2011improved, ), and heavy-tailed (bubeck2013bandits, ) MABs.

In this work, we focus on a broad class of problems that relaxes, at the same time, two core assumptions of the standard MAB problem. In particular, we focus on heavy-tailed non-stationary MABs. Our framework allows for a general class of reward-generating probability distributions without relying on parametric assumptions and with a possibly infinite variance, called heavy-tailed distributions. This setting gained popularity over the last decade due to its applications in finance and telecommunications. Moreover, it extends the assumption of sub-gaussian reward distributions, which is customary in the MAB literature. In such application domains, the assumption that reward-generating distributions are fixed along the whole time horizon is too limiting. It is natural to consider settings, such as finance, characterized by non-stationary processes. We address, with a single algorithm named Robust-CPD-UCB, the problem of learning in non-stationary environments where the noise of the observations can be heavy-tailed. We prove theoretical guarantees over the performance of R-CPD-UCB and show that they are nearly optimal under some mild assumptions. To the best of the authorsâ€™ knowledge, this is the first work to address the problem of regret minimization in non-stationary bandits under infinite-variance reward distributions. In particular, we face the technical challenge of developing the first change-point detection strategy with proven theoretical guarantees for such types of distributions. The contributions are organized as follows:

  • â€¢

    In Section 2, we introduce the definition of the heavy-tailed piecewise-stationary MAB setting. We define the learning problem and introduce a lower bound on the expected regret for this setting.

  • â€¢

    In Section 3, we recall some notions and results from the existing literature on mean estimation for heavy-tailed random variables and on change-point detection.

  • â€¢

    In Section 4, we introduce Robust-CPD-UCB, an algorithm from regret minimization in our setting. We provide theoretical guarantees on its expected regret and insights on choosing its parameters.

  • â€¢

    Finally, in Section 5 (and Appendix C), we provide numerical evaluations of the performance of R-CPD-UCB, comparing it with baselines from the literature on both real-world and synthetic data.

2 Problem Formulation

In this section, we recall the definitions of heavy-tailed and piecewise-stationary bandit. Then, we introduce the heavy-tailed piecewise-stationary bandits, the focus of this work. We formally define the problem of regret minimization and provide a novel regret lower bound for the problem.

2.1 Bandit Settings

Every round tâˆˆ[T]â‰”{1,â€¦,T}ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡â‰”1â€¦ğ‘‡t\in[T]\coloneqq\{1,\ldots,T\}italic_t âˆˆ [ italic_T ] â‰” { 1 , â€¦ , italic_T }, a decision Itâˆˆ[K]subscriptğ¼ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ¾I_{t}\in[K]italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ [ italic_K ] is undertaken (possibly at random) and a reward XIt,tsubscriptğ‘‹subscriptğ¼ğ‘¡ğ‘¡X_{I_{t},t}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is sampled from a probability distribution Î½Itsubscriptğœˆsubscriptğ¼ğ‘¡\nu_{I_{t}}italic_Î½ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We call the set ğ‚={Î½i}iâˆˆ[K]ğ‚subscriptsubscriptğœˆğ‘–ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ¾\bm{\nu}=\{\nu_{i}\}_{i\in[K]}bold_italic_Î½ = { italic_Î½ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_K ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of reward-generating distributions an instance of the MAB (from now on, just MAB). Most of the literature deals with reward-generating distributions either sub-gaussian or with bounded supports.

Heavy-Tailed Bandits.Â Â In heavy-tailed bandits bubeck2013bandits , the probability distributions {Î½i}i=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğœˆğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ¾\{\nu_{i}\}_{i=1}^{K}{ italic_Î½ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are heavy-tailed. In this work, we use the same definition of heavy-tailed MAB (HT MAB, for short).

Definition 2.1 (Heavy-Tailed MAB).

Let Xâˆ¼Î½similar-toğ‘‹ğœˆX\sim\nuitalic_X âˆ¼ italic_Î½ be a random variable with support on â„â„\mathbb{R}blackboard_R. Then, we call Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X a heavy-tailed random variable if it satisfies

ğ”¼Î½â¢[|Xâˆ’ğ”¼Î½â¢[X]|1+Ïµ]â‰¤v,subscriptğ”¼ğœˆdelimited-[]superscriptğ‘‹subscriptğ”¼ğœˆdelimited-[]ğ‘‹1italic-Ïµğ‘£\mathbb{E}_{\nu}[|X-\mathbb{E}_{\nu}[X]|^{1+\epsilon}]\leq v,blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î½ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_X - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î½ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_X ] | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 + italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ italic_v , (1)

for Ïµâˆˆ(0,1]italic-Ïµ01\epsilon\in(0,1]italic_Ïµ âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ] and vâˆˆâ„+ğ‘£superscriptâ„v\in\mathbb{R}^{+}italic_v âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Let ğ‚ğ‚\bm{\nu}bold_italic_Î½ be a MAB. Then, if ğ‚âˆˆâ„‹(v,Ïµ)Kğ‚superscriptsubscriptâ„‹ğ‘£italic-Ïµğ¾\bm{\nu}\in\mathcal{H}_{(v,\epsilon)}^{K}bold_italic_Î½ âˆˆ caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v , italic_Ïµ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where â„‹(v,Ïµ)subscriptâ„‹ğ‘£italic-Ïµ\mathcal{H}_{(v,\epsilon)}caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v , italic_Ïµ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the set of probability distributions satisfying Equation (1), we call ğ‚ğ‚\bm{\nu}bold_italic_Î½ a heavy-tailed bandit (HT MAB, for short).

Note that Equation (1) implies that the variance of the rewards-generating distributions may be infinite (when Ïµ<1italic-Ïµ1\epsilon<1italic_Ïµ < 1). Most of the technical tools employed for sub-gaussian rewards are ineffective for HT MABs. We address readers to genalti2024varepsilon for a recent literature review on HT MABs.

Piecewise-Stationary Bandits.Â Â In standard MABs, the reward-generating distributions are assumed to never change during learning. In non-stationary bandits, instead, the reward-generating distributions are dynamic in time, i.e., the rewards of the same arm are sampled from different distributions depending on the pull time tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T]italic_t âˆˆ [ italic_T ]. However, if there is no constraint on how many times the distributions may change, then the problem may quickly become non-tractable. Thus, in this work, we consider the most popular non-stationary MAB setting, i.e., the piecewise-stationary bandit (PS MAB) from yu2009piecewise , where the distributions of rewards remain constant for a certain period, called epoch, and then abruptly change at some unknown time points, called breakpoints. We assume that the total number of breakpoints Î¥âˆˆ[T]Î¥delimited-[]ğ‘‡\Upsilon\in[T]roman_Î¥ âˆˆ [ italic_T ] is fixed before the trial. We define a PS MAB as follows.

Definition 2.2 (Piecewise-Stationary Bandit).

Let {ğ‚(j)}jâˆˆ[Î¥]subscriptsuperscriptğ‚ğ‘—ğ‘—delimited-[]Î¥\{\bm{\nu}^{(j)}\}_{j\in[\Upsilon]}{ bold_italic_Î½ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j âˆˆ [ roman_Î¥ ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be a set of Î¥Î¥\Upsilonroman_Î¥ MABs. Then, let Î¥Î¥\Upsilonroman_Î¥ be a set of timesteps {tc(j)}jâˆˆ[Î¥]âŠ‚[T]subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘—delimited-[]Î¥delimited-[]ğ‘‡\{t_{c}^{(j)}\}_{j\in[\Upsilon]}\subset[T]{ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j âˆˆ [ roman_Î¥ ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ‚ [ italic_T ] and call Ejsubscriptğ¸ğ‘—E_{j}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the set of indices {tc(jâˆ’1),â€¦,tc(j)}superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘—1â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘—\{t_{c}^{(j-1)},\ldots,t_{c}^{(j)}\}{ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }, where tc(0)=0superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘00t_{c}^{(0)}=0italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0 and tc(Î¥+1)=Tsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘Î¥1ğ‘‡t_{c}^{(\Upsilon+1)}=Titalic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_Î¥ + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_T, by convention. If Î½i(j)superscriptsubscriptğœˆğ‘–ğ‘—\nu_{i}^{(j)}italic_Î½ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the reward-generating distribution of arm iâˆˆ[K]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ¾i\in[K]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_K ] when tâˆˆEjğ‘¡subscriptğ¸ğ‘—t\in E_{j}italic_t âˆˆ italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then ({ğ‚(j)}jâˆˆ[Î¥],{tc(j)}jâˆˆ[Î¥])subscriptsuperscriptğ‚ğ‘—ğ‘—delimited-[]Î¥subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘—delimited-[]Î¥(\{\bm{\nu}^{(j)}\}_{j\in[\Upsilon]},\{t_{c}^{(j)}\}_{j\in[\Upsilon]})( { bold_italic_Î½ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j âˆˆ [ roman_Î¥ ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j âˆˆ [ roman_Î¥ ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) defines a piecewise-stationary bandit (PS MAB, for short).

Ejsubscriptğ¸ğ‘—E_{j}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the jğ‘—jitalic_j-th epoch of the PS MAB, and tc(j)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘—t_{c}^{(j)}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to the jğ‘—jitalic_j-th breakpoint. To simplify notation, we define Î¼i(j)â‰”ğ”¼Î½i(j)â¢[Xi,t]â‰”superscriptsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ”¼superscriptsubscriptğœˆğ‘–ğ‘—delimited-[]subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–ğ‘¡\mu_{i}^{(j)}\coloneqq\mathbb{E}_{\nu_{i}^{(j)}}[X_{i,t}]italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰” blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î½ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] as the mean of the reward-generating distribution of action iğ‘–iitalic_i during epoch jğ‘—jitalic_j. Note that the reward-generating distribution of an action is fixed during an epoch, and so is the mean reward (and every other distribution parameter). We call Î´i(j)â‰”|Î¼i(j)âˆ’Î¼i(jâˆ’1)|â‰”superscriptsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ‘—1\delta_{i}^{(j)}\coloneqq|\mu_{i}^{(j)}-\mu_{i}^{(j-1)}|italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰” | italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | the magnitude of the change in the mean of arm iâˆˆ[K]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ¾i\in[K]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_K ] from epoch Ejâˆ’1subscriptğ¸ğ‘—1E_{j-1}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to the next one, Ejsubscriptğ¸ğ‘—E_{j}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. By convention, E0=âˆ…subscriptğ¸0E_{0}=\emptysetitalic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ… and Î´i(0)=âˆsuperscriptsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘–0\delta_{i}^{(0)}=\inftyitalic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = âˆ for every iâˆˆ[K]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ¾i\in[K]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_K ]. In Appendix A, we review the literature on PS MABs.

Piecewise Non-stationary Heavy-Tailed Bandits.Â Â The general definition of piecewise non-stationary MABs allows for any family of reward-generating distributions, including heavy-tailed ones. In this work, we deal with piecewise non-stationary bandits where the reward-generating distributions satisfy Equation (1). We call this setting the heavy-tailed piecewise-stationary setting (HTPS, for short).

Definition 2.3 (Heavy-Tailed Piecewise-Stationary Bandits).

Let ({ğ‚(j)}jâˆˆ[Î¥],{tc(j)}jâˆˆ[Î¥])subscriptsuperscriptğ‚ğ‘—ğ‘—delimited-[]Î¥subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘—delimited-[]Î¥(\{\bm{\nu}^{(j)}\}_{j\in[\Upsilon]},\{t_{c}^{(j)}\}_{j\in[\Upsilon]})( { bold_italic_Î½ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j âˆˆ [ roman_Î¥ ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j âˆˆ [ roman_Î¥ ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) be a PS bandit. If ğ‚(j)âˆˆâ„‹(v,Ïµ)Ksuperscriptğ‚ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptâ„‹ğ‘£italic-Ïµğ¾\bm{\nu}^{(j)}\in\mathcal{H}_{(v,\epsilon)}^{K}bold_italic_Î½ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v , italic_Ïµ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for every jâˆˆ[Î¥]ğ‘—delimited-[]Î¥j\in[\Upsilon]italic_j âˆˆ [ roman_Î¥ ], we call it a heavy-tailed piecewise-stationary bandit (HTPS MAB, for short). We denote the set of such HTPS MABs as â„¬(v,Ïµ,Î¥,ğ’•c)subscriptâ„¬ğ‘£italic-ÏµÎ¥subscriptğ’•ğ‘\mathcal{B}_{(v,\epsilon,\Upsilon,\bm{t}_{c})}caligraphic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v , italic_Ïµ , roman_Î¥ , bold_italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where ğ’•c={tc(j)}jâˆˆ[Î¥]subscriptğ’•ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘—delimited-[]Î¥\bm{t}_{c}=\{t_{c}^{(j)}\}_{j\in[\Upsilon]}bold_italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j âˆˆ [ roman_Î¥ ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Definition 2.3 introduces the novel bandit setting, as the intersection between HT and PS MABs. To the best of the authorsâ€™ knowledge, this setting has not been studied in previous literature.

2.2 Learning Goal

A policy is a (possibly randomized) map Ï€â¢(t):â„±tâˆ’1â†¦It:ğœ‹ğ‘¡maps-tosubscriptâ„±ğ‘¡1subscriptğ¼ğ‘¡\pi(t):\mathcal{F}_{t-1}\mapsto I_{t}italic_Ï€ ( italic_t ) : caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†¦ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that receives the filtration up to time tâˆ’1ğ‘¡1t-1italic_t - 1 (composed of past actions and rewards) and returns an action Itâˆˆ[K]subscriptğ¼ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ¾I_{t}\in[K]italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ [ italic_K ] to play. We define Î”i(j)superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘—\Delta_{i}^{(j)}roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as the sub-optimality gap of arm iâˆˆ[K]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ¾i\in[K]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_K ] during epoch jâˆˆ[Î¥]ğ‘—delimited-[]Î¥j\in[\Upsilon]italic_j âˆˆ [ roman_Î¥ ], i.e., Î”i(j)â‰”|maxkâˆˆ[K]â¡Î¼k(j)âˆ’Î¼i(j)|â‰”superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘˜ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ‘—\Delta_{i}^{(j)}\coloneqq|\max_{k\in[K]}\mu_{k}^{(j)}-\mu_{i}^{(j)}|roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰” | roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k âˆˆ [ italic_K ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | and Ni,jÏ€â¢(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—ğœ‹ğ‘¡N_{i,j}^{\pi}(t)italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) as the number of times action iğ‘–iitalic_i has been chosen during epoch jğ‘—jitalic_j by policy Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ up to time tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T]italic_t âˆˆ [ italic_T ]. The goal of a learner is to minimize the expected cumulative regret ğ”¼â¢[RÏ€â¢(T)]ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘…ğœ‹ğ‘‡\mathbb{E}[R^{\pi}(T)]blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) ], i.e., the cumulative performance gap w.r.t. to the best policy over a learning horizon.

Definition 2.4 (Expected Cumulative Regret).

Given a policy Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€, we define the expected cumulative regret of Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ as:

ğ”¼â¢[RÏ€â¢(T)]=âˆ‘jâˆˆ[Î¥]âˆ‘iâˆˆ[K]Î”i(j)â¢ğ”¼â¢[Ni,jÏ€â¢(T)],ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘…ğœ‹ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘—delimited-[]Î¥subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ¾superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—ğœ‹ğ‘‡\mathbb{E}[R^{\pi}(T)]=\sum_{j\in[\Upsilon]}\sum_{i\in[K]}\Delta_{i}^{(j)}% \mathbb{E}[N_{i,j}^{\pi}(T)],blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) ] = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j âˆˆ [ roman_Î¥ ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_K ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) ] ,

where the expectation accounts for both the randomness of policy Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ and reward generation.

This performance index is also called dynamic regret and is the standard choice for PS MABs. The optimal policy corresponds to choosing the best action in every epoch jâˆˆ[Î¥]ğ‘—delimited-[]Î¥j\in[\Upsilon]italic_j âˆˆ [ roman_Î¥ ], i.e., ijâˆ—âˆˆargâ¢maxiâˆˆ[K]â¡Î¼k(j)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptargmaxğ‘–delimited-[]ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘˜ğ‘—i^{*}_{j}\in\operatorname*{arg\,max}_{i\in[K]}\mu_{k}^{(j)}italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ start_OPERATOR roman_arg roman_max end_OPERATOR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_K ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We also define some quantities that govern the statistical complexity of the instance. Î´mâ¢iâ¢nâ‰”miniâˆˆ[K],jâˆˆ[Î¥]â¡Î´i(j)â‰”subscriptğ›¿ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›subscriptformulae-sequenceğ‘–delimited-[]ğ¾ğ‘—delimited-[]Î¥superscriptsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ‘—\delta_{min}\coloneqq\min_{i\in[K],j\in[\Upsilon]}\delta_{i}^{(j)}italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_K ] , italic_j âˆˆ [ roman_Î¥ ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the minimum change between any two breakpoints, Î”mâ¢iâ¢n(j)â‰”miniâˆˆ[K],Î”i(j)>0â¡Î”i(j)â‰”superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘—subscriptformulae-sequenceğ‘–delimited-[]ğ¾superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘—0superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘—\Delta_{min}^{(j)}\coloneqq\min_{i\in[K],\Delta_{i}^{(j)}>0}\Delta_{i}^{(j)}roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰” roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_K ] , roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Î”mâ¢aâ¢x(j)â‰”maxiâˆˆ[K]â¡Î”i(j)â‰”superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘—subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ¾superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘—\Delta_{max}^{(j)}\coloneqq\max_{i\in[K]}\Delta_{i}^{(j)}roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰” roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_K ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are the minimum and maximum sub-optimality gap during an epoch jâˆˆ[Î¥]ğ‘—delimited-[]Î¥j\in[\Upsilon]italic_j âˆˆ [ roman_Î¥ ], respectively. Intuitively, the smaller Î´mâ¢iâ¢n(j)superscriptsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘—\delta_{min}^{(j)}italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is, the more difficult it is to detect breakpoints, and the smaller Î”mâ¢iâ¢n(j)superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘—\Delta_{min}^{(j)}roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is, the more difficult it is to distinguish the best action. On the other hand, the larger these quantities are, the larger the regret potentially incurred with an error. When (j)ğ‘—(j)( italic_j ) is omitted, we refer to the quantity minimized/maximized over all epochs.

2.3 Lower Bound

In this section, we provide a lower bound to the expected cumulative regret that any policy Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ must incur in an HTPS bandit.

Theorem 2.5 (Regret Lower Bound for the HTPS Bandit Problem).

For any fixed policy Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€, we have

supğ‚âˆˆâ„¬(v,Ïµ,Î¥)ğ”¼ğ‚â¢[RÏ€â¢(T)]subscriptsupremumğ‚subscriptâ„¬ğ‘£italic-ÏµÎ¥subscriptğ”¼ğ‚delimited-[]superscriptğ‘…ğœ‹ğ‘‡\displaystyle\sup_{\bm{\nu}\in\mathcal{B}_{(v,\epsilon,\Upsilon)}}\mathbb{E}_{% \bm{\nu}}[R^{\pi}(T)]roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î½ âˆˆ caligraphic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v , italic_Ïµ , roman_Î¥ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î½ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) ] â‰¥125â¢(Kâ¢Î¥)Ïµ1+Ïµâ¢(vâ¢T)11+Ïµ.absent125superscriptğ¾Î¥italic-Ïµ1italic-Ïµsuperscriptğ‘£ğ‘‡11italic-Ïµ\displaystyle\geq\frac{1}{25}(K\Upsilon)^{\frac{\epsilon}{1+\epsilon}}(vT)^{% \frac{1}{1+\epsilon}}.â‰¥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 25 end_ARG ( italic_K roman_Î¥ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_v italic_T ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (2)

Results of this type are known as minimax lower bounds. Indeed, the result states that, for every policy, there exists at least one instance in which the expected regret grows at a certain rate. The bound is consistent with the known lower bounds for the HT and PS MAB problems. Indeed, in HT MABs every policy has its expected regret lower bounded by Î©â¢(KÏµ1+Ïµâ¢T11+Ïµ)Î©superscriptğ¾italic-Ïµ1italic-Ïµsuperscriptğ‘‡11italic-Ïµ\Omega(K^{\frac{\epsilon}{1+\epsilon}}T^{\frac{1}{1+\epsilon}})roman_Î© ( italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) (bubeck2013bandits, ), while in PS MABs the lower bound is Î©â¢(Kâ¢Î¥â¢T)Î©ğ¾Î¥ğ‘‡\Omega(\sqrt{K\Upsilon T})roman_Î© ( square-root start_ARG italic_K roman_Î¥ italic_T end_ARG ) (garivier2011upper, ). Thus, Equation (2) is a natural combination of these two results that can be recovered by either setting Î¥=1Î¥1\Upsilon=1roman_Î¥ = 1 or Ïµ=1italic-Ïµ1\epsilon=1italic_Ïµ = 1. We refer to Appendix B for the proof.

3 Technical Preliminaries

In this section, we introduce the technical tools we employ in our proposed solution. First, we discuss the mean estimation for HT random variables and describe the Catoni estimator. Then, we formalize the change-point detection (CPD) problem and discuss a technique based on confidence sequences.

3.1 Mean Estimation for Heavy-Tailed Random Variables with Catoni Estimator

Mean estimation for HT variables can be quite a delicate task. Empirical mean has been proved to achieve a sub-optimal concentration (bubeck2013bandits, ). However, alternative estimators enjoying optimal rates have been proposed. We focus on the elegant Catoni estimator (catoni2012challenging, ), defined using a Catoni-type influence function Ï•:â„â†’â„:italic-Ï•â†’â„â„\phi:\mathbb{R}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}italic_Ï• : blackboard_R â†’ blackboard_R. The Catoni estimator Î¼^csubscript^ğœ‡ğ‘\widehat{\mu}_{c}over^ start_ARG italic_Î¼ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for a sequence of variables {Xi}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›\{X_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}{ italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the solution of:

âˆ‘i=1nÏ•Ïµâ¢(Î»iâ¢(Xiâˆ’Î¼^c))=0,whereÏ•Ïµâ¢(x)=logâ¡(1+|x|+|x|1+Ïµ1+Ïµ),formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptitalic-Ï•italic-Ïµsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–subscript^ğœ‡ğ‘0wheresubscriptitalic-Ï•italic-Ïµğ‘¥1ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥1italic-Ïµ1italic-Ïµ\sum_{i=1}^{n}\phi_{\epsilon}(\lambda_{i}(X_{i}-\widehat{\mu}_{c}))=0,\quad% \text{where}\quad\phi_{\epsilon}(x)=\log\left(1+|x|+\frac{|x|^{1+\epsilon}}{1+% \epsilon}\right),âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over^ start_ARG italic_Î¼ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = 0 , where italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = roman_log ( 1 + | italic_x | + divide start_ARG | italic_x | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 + italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG ) , (3)

and {Î»i}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›\{\lambda_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}{ italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a predictable process. Remarkably, for a proper choice of {Î»i}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›\{\lambda_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}{ italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, this estimator enjoys an optimal concentration of order ğ’ªâ¢((v1Ïµâ¢logâ¡(Î´âˆ’1)n)Ïµ1+Ïµ)ğ’ªsuperscriptsuperscriptğ‘£1italic-Ïµsuperscriptğ›¿1ğ‘›italic-Ïµ1italic-Ïµ\mathcal{O}\Big{(}\Big{(}\frac{v^{\frac{1}{\epsilon}}\log(\delta^{-1})}{n}\Big% {)}^{\frac{\epsilon}{1+\epsilon}}\Big{)}caligraphic_O ( ( divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( italic_Î´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) with probability 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta1 - italic_Î´ bhatt2022catoni .

3.2 Confidence Sequences and Change Point Detection

The PS MAB is often addressed by resorting to change-point detection (CPD) strategies, e.g., CUSUM-UCB (liu2018change, ). The idea is to actively adapt to environmental changes and tackle the problem as a sequence of stationary MABs. These strategies are often restricted to sub-gaussian rewards and do not scale on heavy-tailed variables. We propose an alternative approach to tackle this family of problems using a CPD strategy based on confidence sequences.

Confidence Sequences.Â Â Suppose {Xt}tâˆˆâ„•âˆ¼Psimilar-tosubscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡ğ‘¡â„•ğ‘ƒ\{X_{t}\}_{t\in\mathbb{N}}\sim P{ italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆˆ blackboard_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_P for some Pâˆˆğ’«Î¼ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ’«ğœ‡P\in\mathcal{P}^{\mu}italic_P âˆˆ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¼ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT where ğ’«Î¼superscriptğ’«ğœ‡\mathcal{P}^{\mu}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¼ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the set of distributions on âˆtâˆˆâ„•â„subscriptproductğ‘¡â„•â„\prod_{t\in\mathbb{N}}\mathbb{R}âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆˆ blackboard_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R such that ğ”¼â¢[Xt|â„±tâˆ’1]=Î¼ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡subscriptâ„±ğ‘¡1ğœ‡\mathbb{E}[X_{t}|\mathcal{F}_{t-1}]=\mublackboard_E [ italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = italic_Î¼ for each tâˆˆâ„•ğ‘¡â„•t\in\mathbb{N}italic_t âˆˆ blackboard_N, where â„±tâˆ’1subscriptâ„±ğ‘¡1\mathcal{F}_{t-1}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the filtration. A confidence sequence (CS) for the mean is a sequence of confidence intervals {CIt}tâˆˆâ„•subscriptsubscriptCIğ‘¡ğ‘¡â„•\{\text{CI}_{t}\}_{t\in\mathbb{N}}{ CI start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆˆ blackboard_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT holding at arbitrary data-dependent stopping times. Formally:

â„™(âˆ€tâˆˆâ„•+:Î¼âˆˆCIt)â‰¥1âˆ’Î³.\mathbb{P}(\forall t\in\mathbb{N}^{+}:\mu\in\text{CI}_{t})\geq 1-\gamma.blackboard_P ( âˆ€ italic_t âˆˆ blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : italic_Î¼ âˆˆ CI start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¥ 1 - italic_Î³ . (4)

The random intervals {CIt}tâˆˆâ„•+subscriptsubscriptCIğ‘¡ğ‘¡superscriptâ„•\{\text{CI}_{t}\}_{t\in\mathbb{N}^{+}}{ CI start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆˆ blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that satisfy property (4) are called (1âˆ’Î³)1ğ›¾(1-\gamma)( 1 - italic_Î³ )-CS, where 1âˆ’Î³1ğ›¾1-\gamma1 - italic_Î³ is the confidence level. For a CS defined on â„â„\mathbb{R}blackboard_R, we formally introduce its width after tğ‘¡titalic_t samples defined as wâ¢(t,P,Î³)â‰”supÎ¼1,Î¼2âˆˆCâ¢It|Î¼1âˆ’Î¼2|â‰¤wâ¢(t,P,Î³)â‰”ğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğ‘ƒğ›¾subscriptsupremumsubscriptğœ‡1subscriptğœ‡2ğ¶subscriptğ¼ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‡1subscriptğœ‡2ğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğ‘ƒğ›¾w(t,P,\gamma)\coloneqq\sup_{\mu_{1},\mu_{2}\in CI_{t}}|\mu_{1}-\mu_{2}|\leq w(% t,P,\gamma)italic_w ( italic_t , italic_P , italic_Î³ ) â‰” roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_C italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | â‰¤ italic_w ( italic_t , italic_P , italic_Î³ ), for all Pâˆˆğ’«Î¼ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ’«ğœ‡P\in\mathcal{P}^{\mu}italic_P âˆˆ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¼ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Î³âˆˆ(0,1]ğ›¾01\gamma\in(0,1]italic_Î³ âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ].

Change-Point Detection.Â Â  Consider a data-generating process composed of infinitely-countable distributions {Pt}tâˆˆâ„•subscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘¡ğ‘¡â„•\{P_{t}\}_{t\in\mathbb{N}}{ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆˆ blackboard_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and let tcâ‰¥1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘1t_{c}\geq 1italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 1 be an unknown breakpoint, i.e., Pt=P0subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ƒ0P_{t}=P_{0}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for every tâ‰¤tcğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘t\leq t_{c}italic_t â‰¤ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Pt=P1subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{t}=P_{1}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for every t>tcğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘t>t_{c}italic_t > italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The goal of a CPD algorithm is to detect, as soon as possible after tcsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘t_{c}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, that a change in the data-generating distribution happened. In other words, given the (stochastic) stopping time Ï„âˆˆâ„•ğœâ„•\tau\in\mathbb{N}italic_Ï„ âˆˆ blackboard_N in which the CPD system detects a change, the objective is to minimize the detection delay ğ”¼tcâ¢[Ï„âˆ’tc]subscriptğ”¼subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘delimited-[]ğœsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘\mathbb{E}_{t_{c}}[\tau-t_{c}]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Ï„ - italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ], where the expectation ğ”¼tcsubscriptğ”¼subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘\mathbb{E}_{t_{c}}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is taken over an environment having a change-point after tcsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘t_{c}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT rounds. A trivial CPD system yielding a signal at every round would minimize this quantity. On the other hand, we also desire to reduce the false alarm rate (FAR), i.e., the probability that a signal is produced when no change happens. This translates into minimizing â„™âˆâ¢(Ï„<âˆ)subscriptâ„™ğœ\mathbb{P}_{\infty}(\tau<\infty)blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï„ < âˆ ), where â„™âˆsubscriptâ„™\mathbb{P}_{\infty}blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the probability measure of the environment where there is no change-point. Moreover, the average run length (ARL), defined as ğ”¼âˆâ¢[Ï„]subscriptğ”¼delimited-[]ğœ\mathbb{E}_{\infty}[\tau]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Ï„ ], represents the expected number of rounds before a change is erroneously detected. However, when ARL is too large (e.g., the trivial CPD that never yields a signal), the system is too conservative, impacting the detection delay. This highlights a crucial trade-off between detection delay and ARL. Recent literature (shekhar2023sequential, ; shekhar2023reducing, ) shed light on the possibility of reducing CPD to a sequential estimation, i.e., producing sequential testing via confidence sequences. We focus on the repeated-FCS-detector framework, introduced in shekhar2023reducing . repeated-FCS-detector is a meta-algorithm that requires a CS computation strategy and uses it as a black-box tool, defined as:

Definition 3.1 (repeated-FCS-detector, shekhar2023reducing ).

Let {Xt}tâˆˆâ„•subscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡ğ‘¡â„•\{X_{t}\}_{t\in\mathbb{N}}{ italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆˆ blackboard_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be a sequence of observations. At every round tğ‘¡titalic_t, we receive a new sample Xtsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡X_{t}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and initialize a new (1âˆ’Î³)1ğ›¾(1-\gamma)( 1 - italic_Î³ )-CS for the mean CS(t)â‰”{CIn(t)}nâ‰¥tâ‰”superscriptCSğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptCIğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘›ğ‘¡\text{CS}^{(t)}\coloneqq\{\text{CI}_{n}^{(t)}\}_{n\geq t}CS start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰” { CI start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n â‰¥ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, formed using samples Xtsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡X_{t}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Xt+1subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡1X_{t+1}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Xt+2subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡2X_{t+2}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and onwards. Moreover, we update all previously initialized CS {CI(i)}i<tsubscriptsuperscriptCIğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘¡\{\text{CI}^{(i)}\}_{i<t}{ CI start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i < italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT using Xtsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡X_{t}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We define the stopping time, Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„, as the first time at which the intersection of all initialized CS becomes empty, i.e., Ï„=inftâˆˆâ„•{â‹‚n=0tCS(n)=âˆ…}ğœsubscriptinfimumğ‘¡â„•superscriptsubscriptğ‘›0ğ‘¡superscriptCSğ‘›\tau=\inf_{t\in\mathbb{N}}\{\bigcap_{n=0}^{t}\text{CS}^{(n)}=\emptyset\}italic_Ï„ = roman_inf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆˆ blackboard_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { â‹‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT CS start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = âˆ… }.

Provided an oracle capable of computing a (1âˆ’Î³)1ğ›¾(1-\gamma)( 1 - italic_Î³ )-CS at every round, this strategy is distribution agnostic, as it requires no additional information about the data-generating distribution nor the change point. In shekhar2023reducing , theoretical guarantees on both the ARL and the detection delay of repeated-FCS-detector are provided expressed in terms of the width of the (1âˆ’Î³)1ğ›¾(1-\gamma)( 1 - italic_Î³ )-CS provided to the detector. We now report the theoretical guarantees of repeated-FCS-detector.

Theorem 3.2 (Guarantees of repeated-FCS-detector, shekhar2023reducing ).

Consider a CPD problem with observations {Xt}tâˆˆâ„•subscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡ğ‘¡â„•\{X_{t}\}_{t\in\mathbb{N}}{ italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆˆ blackboard_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT i.i.d. from P0âˆˆğ’«Î¼0subscriptğ‘ƒ0superscriptğ’«subscriptğœ‡0P_{0}\in\mathcal{P}^{\mu_{0}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for tâ‰¤tcğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘t\leq t_{c}italic_t â‰¤ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and from P1âˆˆğ’«Î¼1subscriptğ‘ƒ1superscriptğ’«subscriptğœ‡1P_{1}\in\mathcal{P}^{\mu_{1}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for t>tcğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘t>t_{c}italic_t > italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let Î´â‰”|Î¼1âˆ’Î¼0|â‰”ğ›¿subscriptğœ‡1subscriptğœ‡0\delta\coloneqq|\mu_{1}-\mu_{0}|italic_Î´ â‰” | italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT |. Suppose we can construct (1âˆ’Î³)1ğ›¾(1-\gamma)( 1 - italic_Î³ )-confidence sequences with pointwise width wâ¢(t,P0,Î³)ğ‘¤ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ƒ0ğ›¾w(t,P_{0},\gamma)italic_w ( italic_t , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î³ ) and wâ¢(t,P1,Î³)ğ‘¤ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ƒ1ğ›¾w(t,P_{1},\gamma)italic_w ( italic_t , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î³ ) for pre- and post-change mean, respectively. Then, we have: (i) When there is no changepoint, the repeated-FCS-detector satisfies ğ”¼âˆâ¢[Ï„]â‰¥1Î³subscriptğ”¼delimited-[]ğœ1ğ›¾\mathbb{E}_{\infty}[\tau]\geq\frac{1}{\gamma}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Ï„ ] â‰¥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG; (ii) Suppose tc<âˆsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘t_{c}<\inftyitalic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < âˆ and large enough to ensure that wâ¢(tc,Î¼0,Î³)<Î´ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘subscriptğœ‡0ğ›¾ğ›¿w(t_{c},\mu_{0},\gamma)<\deltaitalic_w ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î³ ) < italic_Î´. Introduce the event â„°={Î¼0âˆˆâ‹‚t=1tcCâ¢It(1)}â„°subscriptğœ‡0superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ¶superscriptsubscriptğ¼ğ‘¡1\mathcal{E}=\{\mu_{0}\in\bigcap_{t=1}^{t_{c}}CI_{t}^{(1)}\}caligraphic_E = { italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ â‹‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }, and note that â„™â¢(â„°)â‰¥1âˆ’Î³â„™â„°1ğ›¾\mathbb{P}(\mathcal{E})\geq 1-\gammablackboard_P ( caligraphic_E ) â‰¥ 1 - italic_Î³ by construction. Then, for Î³âˆˆ(0,0.5)ğ›¾00.5\gamma\in(0,0.5)italic_Î³ âˆˆ ( 0 , 0.5 ), we have ğ”¼tcâ¢[(Ï„âˆ’tc)+|â„°]â‰¤3â¢u0â¢(Î¼0,Î¼1,tc)1âˆ’Î³subscriptğ”¼subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptğœsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘â„°3subscriptğ‘¢0subscriptğœ‡0subscriptğœ‡1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘1ğ›¾\mathbb{E}_{t_{c}}[(\tau-t_{c})^{+}|\mathcal{E}]\leq\frac{3u_{0}(\mu_{0},\mu_{% 1},t_{c})}{1-\gamma}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_Ï„ - italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | caligraphic_E ] â‰¤ divide start_ARG 3 italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_Î³ end_ARG, where u0â¢(Î¼0,Î¼1,tc)â‰”minnâˆˆâ„•â¡{wâ¢(n,Î¼1,Î³)+wâ¢(tc,Î¼0,Î³)<Î´}â‰”subscriptğ‘¢0subscriptğœ‡0subscriptğœ‡1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘subscriptğ‘›â„•ğ‘¤ğ‘›subscriptğœ‡1ğ›¾ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘subscriptğœ‡0ğ›¾ğ›¿u_{0}(\mu_{0},\mu_{1},t_{c})\coloneqq\min_{n\in\mathbb{N}}\{w(n,\mu_{1},\gamma% )+w(t_{c},\mu_{0},\gamma)<\delta\}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰” roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n âˆˆ blackboard_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_w ( italic_n , italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î³ ) + italic_w ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î³ ) < italic_Î´ }.

Point (i) provides a lower bound on the ARL of repeated-FCS-detector, while (ii) upper bounds the expected detection delay. While ARL only depends on the desired confidence level, the detection delay depends on the width of the CSs. Indeed, the width of the CS must decrease fast enough to make the change detectable. This assumption is standard in CPD, as enough samples before the change are needed to model the null hypothesis correctly.

4 Robust Regret Minimization in Piecewise-Stationary Heavy-Tailed Bandits

In this section, we describe our strategy for regret minimization in HTPS MABs. We start by providing a CPD strategy suited for heavy-tailed random variables together with its theoretical guarantees. Then, we leverage this tool to build a meta-algorithm named Robust-CPD-UCB, which uses a regret minimizer for the stationary setting and the CPD strategy to tackle non-stationarity.

4.1 Catoni-FCS-detector

We start by introducing a novel CPD strategy for HT random variables, which we name Catoni-FCS-detector, based on a repeated-FCS-detector using a special type of CS. We can define Catoni-FCS-detector as a special instantiation of repeated-FCS-detector.

Definition 4.1 (Catoni-FCS-detector).

An instance of repeated-FCS-detector is a Catoni-FCS-detector if the (1âˆ’Î³)1ğ›¾(1-\gamma)( 1 - italic_Î³ )-CS {CItÏ•}tâˆˆâ„•subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptCIğ‘¡italic-Ï•ğ‘¡â„•\{\text{CI}_{t}^{\phi}\}_{t\in\mathbb{N}}{ CI start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï• end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆˆ blackboard_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is defined as:

Câ¢ItÏ•={mâˆˆâ„:âˆ‘i=1tÏ•Ïµâ¢(Î»iâ¢(Xiâˆ’m))âˆˆ[âˆ“v2â¢âˆ‘i=1tÎ»i1+ÏµÂ±logâ¡(2Î³)]},ğ¶superscriptsubscriptğ¼ğ‘¡italic-Ï•conditional-setğ‘šâ„superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘¡subscriptitalic-Ï•italic-Ïµsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–ğ‘šdelimited-[]plus-or-minusminus-or-plusğ‘£2superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–1italic-Ïµ2ğ›¾\displaystyle CI_{t}^{\phi}=\bigg{\{}m\in\mathbb{R}:\sum_{i=1}^{t}\phi_{% \epsilon}(\lambda_{i}(X_{i}-m))\in\bigg{[}\mp\frac{v}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{t}\lambda_% {i}^{1+\epsilon}\pm\log\bigg{(}\frac{2}{\gamma}\bigg{)}\bigg{]}\bigg{\}},italic_C italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï• end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { italic_m âˆˆ blackboard_R : âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_m ) ) âˆˆ [ âˆ“ divide start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 + italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Â± roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG ) ] } , (5)

where Ï•Ïµsubscriptitalic-Ï•italic-Ïµ\phi_{\epsilon}italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the Catoni-type influence function (Equation 3).

From now on, we call Catoni CS the confidence sequence defined as in Equation (5). Catoni CS have been introduced for the first time in wang2023catoni . While a Catoni CS does not admit a trivial closed-form representation, it can be proven (see Appendix B) that Equation (5) represents a proper (1âˆ’Î³)1ğ›¾(1-\gamma)( 1 - italic_Î³ )-CS for the mean, attaining an optimal width (bhatt2022catoni, ). To use Catoni-FCS-detector in a bandit problem, however, we need specific types of guarantees, different than the ones provided for the general repeated-FCS-detector framework. We now provide two novel contributions of independent interest. First, we show how the width of the Catoni CS can be narrowed further w.r.t. to the one presented in previous works in the case of infinite variance. Second, we provide a finite-time bound on the detection delay of Catoni-FCS-detector, a crucial property for using a CPD in a bandit.

Proposition 4.2 (Detection Delay of Catoni-FCS-detector).

Consider a CPD problem with observations {Xt}tâˆˆâ„•subscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡ğ‘¡â„•\{X_{t}\}_{t\in\mathbb{N}}{ italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆˆ blackboard_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT drawn i.i.d. from P0âˆˆâ„‹Ïµ,vâˆ©ğ’«Î¼0subscriptğ‘ƒ0subscriptâ„‹italic-Ïµğ‘£superscriptğ’«subscriptğœ‡0P_{0}\in\mathcal{H}_{\epsilon,v}\cap\mathcal{P}^{\mu_{0}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ , italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for tâ‰¤tcğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘t\leq t_{c}italic_t â‰¤ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and from P1âˆˆâ„‹Ïµ,vâˆ©ğ’«Î¼1subscriptğ‘ƒ1subscriptâ„‹italic-Ïµğ‘£superscriptğ’«subscriptğœ‡1P_{1}\in\mathcal{H}_{\epsilon,v}\cap\mathcal{P}^{\mu_{1}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ , italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for t>tcğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘t>t_{c}italic_t > italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let Î´â‰”|Î¼1âˆ’Î¼0|â‰”ğ›¿subscriptğœ‡1subscriptğœ‡0\delta\coloneqq|\mu_{1}-\mu_{0}|italic_Î´ â‰” | italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT |. Suppose that there exists a known upper bound Tğ‘‡Titalic_T of the change point (tcâ‰¤Tsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘‡t_{c}\leq Titalic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_T). Let nmâ¢iâ¢nâ‰”68â¢logâ¡(T1+ÏµÏµ)â‰”subscriptğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›68superscriptğ‘‡1italic-Ïµitalic-Ïµn_{min}\coloneqq 68\log(T^{\frac{1+\epsilon}{\epsilon}})italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” 68 roman_log ( italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and suppose tcâ‰¥nmâ¢iâ¢nsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘subscriptğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›t_{c}\geq n_{min}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT large enough s.t. wâ¢(tc,P0,Î³)â‰¤Î´2ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘subscriptğ‘ƒ0ğ›¾ğ›¿2w(t_{c},P_{0},\gamma)\leq\frac{\delta}{2}italic_w ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î³ ) â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG. Set Î³=2T3ğ›¾2superscriptğ‘‡3\gamma=\frac{2}{T^{3}}italic_Î³ = divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG. Then, there exists a predictable sequence {Î»i}i=1Tsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘‡\{\lambda_{i}\}_{i=1}^{T}{ italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT s.t. Catoni-FCS-detector enjoys (i) â„™tcâ¢((Ï„âˆ’tc)+â‰¤ğ’ªâ¢(v1Ïµâ¢logâ¡(T)Î´1+ÏµÏµ))â‰¥1âˆ’14Tsubscriptâ„™subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘superscriptğœsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ’ªsuperscriptğ‘£1italic-Ïµğ‘‡superscriptğ›¿1italic-Ïµitalic-Ïµ114ğ‘‡\mathbb{P}_{t_{c}}\left((\tau-t_{c})^{+}\leq\mathcal{O}\left(v^{\frac{1}{% \epsilon}}\frac{\log(T)}{\delta^{\frac{1+\epsilon}{\epsilon}}}\right)\right)% \geq 1-\frac{14}{T}blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ( italic_Ï„ - italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ caligraphic_O ( italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG roman_log ( italic_T ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) ) â‰¥ 1 - divide start_ARG 14 end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG and (ii) â„™tcâ¢(Ï„<tc)â‰¤14Tsubscriptâ„™subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğœsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘14ğ‘‡\mathbb{P}_{t_{c}}\left(\tau<t_{c}\right)\leq\frac{14}{T}blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï„ < italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¤ divide start_ARG 14 end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG.

We point out the importance of this specialized result. Since the guarantees of Theorem 3.2 are very general, this result is aimed at providing a finite-time, high-probability bound on the detection delay when using Catoni CS. In particular, we make the term u0â¢(Î¼0,Î¼1,tc)subscriptğ‘¢0subscriptğœ‡0subscriptğœ‡1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘u_{0}(\mu_{0},\mu_{1},t_{c})italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) from Theorem 3.2 explicit by using the properties of Catoni CS. Due to space reasons, the proof is postponed to Appendix B. Note that the rate of this detection delay cannot be improved as the lower bound for the detection delay of any distribution change is Î©â¢(logâ¡(Î³âˆ’1))Î©superscriptğ›¾1\Omega(\log(\gamma^{-1}))roman_Î© ( roman_log ( italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) (lorden1971procedures, ), where Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ the confidence parameter that we set to ğ’ªâ¢(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(1/T)caligraphic_O ( 1 / italic_T ). Moreover, the dependencies on Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´, Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ and vğ‘£vitalic_v may also be tight, as they embed the log-likelihood ratio of the test for the means of heavy-tailed random variables. We leave the answer to this question for further investigations. We conclude this section with two important remarks.

Remark 4.3 (Comparison with Existing CPDs).

Catoni-FCS-detector is, to the best of authorsâ€™ knowledge, the first CPD strategy for the mean of HT random variables with infinite variance enjoying such guarantees. Thus, we consider our analysis an interesting standalone contribution. In bandit literature, however, many CPD strategies have been employed, (e.g., CUSUM (liu2018change, ) and GLR Test (besson2022efficient, )). However, they do not cover the HT scenario and often rely on strong parametric assumptions on the sample-generating distribution, e.g., only working on Bernoulli variables.

Remark 4.4 (On the a priori knowledge of Catoni-FCS-detector).

Catoni-FCS-detector does not rely, in principle, on any prior knowledge of the magnitude of the change or on the means. The confidence parameter Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ is set based on the time horizon Tğ‘‡Titalic_T, which is standard in MABs. Moreover, the sequence {Î»i}i=1tsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘¡\{\lambda_{i}\}_{i=1}^{t}{ italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can be set in advance for every tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T]italic_t âˆˆ [ italic_T ], only relying on the knowledge of Tğ‘‡Titalic_T.

4.2 Robust-CPD-UCB

In this section, we introduce Robust-CPD-UCB (R-CPD-UCB for short, Algorithm 1), an algorithm for PS HT bandits. R-CPD-UCB actively adapts to the changes in the reward-generating distribution. The algorithm has three components: (1)1(1)( 1 ) a sub-algorithm suited for the stationary HT MAB problem, that aims to minimize the regret in the stationary segments, we call this policy Ï€ssubscriptğœ‹ğ‘ \pi_{s}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; (2)2(2)( 2 ) the Catoni-FCS-detector strategy for CPD; and (3)3(3)( 3 ) a cyclic uniform exploration that ensures the availability of enough samples for every action to perform the CPD test. Algorithm 1 proceeds as follows: roughly every âŒŠK/Î·âŒ‹ğ¾ğœ‚\lfloor K/\eta\rfloorâŒŠ italic_K / italic_Î· âŒ‹ rounds it tries all the actions once (lines 4-5), this ensures that CPD can happen efficiently even when underrepresented actions in the history are the only ones changing. In the other rounds, a bandit sub-routine (e.g., Robust-UCB) plays according to all the history since the last reset (lines 8-9); once the new reward is obtained, it is fed to the Catoni-FCS-detector that verifies if a change point occurred (lines 12-14), in this case, everything is reset (line 15-16).

Remark 4.5.

(Connection to Monitored-UCB from cao2019nearly ) Robust-CPD-UCB borrows the idea of cyclic uniform exploration from the Monitored-UCB cao2019nearly . Moreover, as most of the algorithms for the PS setting, ours share the usage of a stationary bandit sub-routine. However, a crucial difference relies on the type of CPD strategy employed. Monitored-UCB leverages a sliding-window type of CPD strategy that checks if the average of the first half of the sliding-window is significantly different from that of the second half. This type of CPD strategy requires two hyper-parameters, the window size and the threshold, respectively. Tuning these parameters may be difficult, even though, in practice, the algorithm works well even under misspecification. Finally, Monitored-UCB only deals with rewards bounded in [0,1]01[0,1][ 0 , 1 ], while Robust-CPD-UCB deals with HT rewards.

Remark 4.6.

(Priori Knowledge of R-CPD-UCB) Algorithm 1 receives as inputs the time horizon Tğ‘‡Titalic_T, the uniform exploration coefficient Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î·, and a regret minimizer for the stationary setting Ï€ssubscriptğœ‹ğ‘ {\pi_{s}}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT only. Assuming that it is possible to choose a regret minimizer that does not require additional parameters other than Tğ‘‡Titalic_T (which is, as we will show in the next section, rather natural), then the only knowledge that R-CPD-UCB requires on the environment is the time horizon Tğ‘‡Titalic_T. Thus, in principle, our algorithm requires knowledge of Tğ‘‡Titalic_T only. In practice, this property ensures that no tuning must happen.

4.3 Theoretical Guarantees of Robust-CPD-UCB

As customary in the literature of PS MABs, we introduce a technical assumption regarding the length of any epoch ensuring that exploration is frequent enough to detect for every action.

Assumption 4.7.

For every epoch jâˆˆ[Î¥]ğ‘—delimited-[]Î¥j\in[\Upsilon]italic_j âˆˆ [ roman_Î¥ ], let Î´~mâ¢iâ¢n(j)â‰”minâ¡{Î´mâ¢iâ¢n(jâˆ’1),Î´mâ¢iâ¢n(j)}â‰”superscriptsubscript~ğ›¿ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘—1superscriptsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘—\widetilde{\delta}_{min}^{(j)}\coloneqq\min\{\delta_{min}^{(j-1)},\delta_{min}% ^{(j)}\}over~ start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰” roman_min { italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }, and let |Ej|subscriptğ¸ğ‘—|E_{j}|| italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | be its length and Ljâ‰”6â¢(236)1+ÏµÏµâ¢v1Ïµâ¢logâ¡(logâ¡(1/Î´~mâ¢iâ¢n(j)))+logâ¡(T)(Î´~mâ¢iâ¢n(j))1+ÏµÏµâ‰”subscriptğ¿ğ‘—6superscript2361italic-Ïµitalic-Ïµsuperscriptğ‘£1italic-Ïµ1superscriptsubscript~ğ›¿ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘—ğ‘‡superscriptsuperscriptsubscript~ğ›¿ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘—1italic-Ïµitalic-ÏµL_{j}\coloneqq 6(236)^{\frac{1+\epsilon}{\epsilon}}v^{\frac{1}{\epsilon}}\frac% {\log\left(\log\left(1/{{\widetilde{\delta}_{min}^{(j)}}}\right)\right)+\log(T% )}{(\widetilde{\delta}_{min}^{(j)})^{\frac{1+\epsilon}{\epsilon}}}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” 6 ( 236 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG roman_log ( roman_log ( 1 / over~ start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) + roman_log ( italic_T ) end_ARG start_ARG ( over~ start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG. The learner can select Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· such that, for every jâˆˆ[Î¥]ğ‘—delimited-[]Î¥j\in[\Upsilon]italic_j âˆˆ [ roman_Î¥ ], it holds that |Ej|â‰¥2â¢nmâ¢iâ¢n+2â¢âŒˆLjâ¢K/Î·âŒ‰subscriptğ¸ğ‘—2subscriptğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›2subscriptğ¿ğ‘—ğ¾ğœ‚|E_{j}|\geq 2n_{min}+2\left\lceil L_{j}{K}/{\eta}\right\rceil| italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | â‰¥ 2 italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 âŒˆ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K / italic_Î· âŒ‰.

This assumption ensures that proper learning can be performed in such an environment Indeed, we enforce that every epoch jâˆˆ[Î¥]ğ‘—delimited-[]Î¥j\in[\Upsilon]italic_j âˆˆ [ roman_Î¥ ] is large enough so that, due to the forced exploration only, the algorithm chooses every action at least Ljsubscriptğ¿ğ‘—L_{j}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT times. This kind of assumption is ubiquitous in the piecewise-stationary bandits literature. Notable examples include Assumptions 4 and 7 in (besson2022efficient, ), Assumptions 1 and 2 in (cao2019nearly, ) and Assumption 1 in (liu2018change, ). Some are equivalent to ours, while others are neither weaker nor stronger. Alternative assumptions, such as the monotonicity of the mean change, also allow for theoretical tractability, e.g., Assumption 1 in (seznec2020single, ), which forces expected rewards to evolve in a decreasing manner. Note that Assumption 4.7 is a technical assumption aimed at the theoretical analysis of the algorithm. Algorithm 1 can operate regardless of this assumption, as shown in Section 5. We are now ready to present our main result.

Theorem 4.8 (Regret Upper Bound of R-CPD-UCB).

Under Assumption 4.7, R-CPD-UCB suffers an expected cumulative regret bounded as:

ğ”¼â¢[RÏ€R-CPD-UCBâ¢(T)]â‰¤ğ’ªâ¢(âˆ‘j=1Î¥v1Ïµâ¢logâ¡(T)(Î´~mâ¢iâ¢n(j))1+ÏµÏµâ¢âŒˆKÎ·âŒ‰â¢Î”mâ¢aâ¢x(j)âŸ(A) Detection Delay Contribution+âˆ‘j=1Î¥ğ”¼â¢[RÏ€sâ¢(|Ej|)]âŸ(B) Stationary Policy Regret+Î·â¢âˆ‘j=1Î¥|Ej|â¢Î”mâ¢aâ¢x(j)âŸ(C) Uniform Exploration).ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘…superscriptğœ‹R-CPD-UCBğ‘‡ğ’ªsubscriptâŸsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1Î¥superscriptğ‘£1italic-Ïµğ‘‡superscriptsuperscriptsubscript~ğ›¿ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘—1italic-Ïµitalic-Ïµğ¾ğœ‚superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘—(A) Detection Delay ContributionsubscriptâŸsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1Î¥ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘…subscriptğœ‹ğ‘ subscriptğ¸ğ‘—(B) Stationary Policy RegretsubscriptâŸğœ‚superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1Î¥subscriptğ¸ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘—(C) Uniform Exploration\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[R^{\pi^{\text{\emph{R-CPD-UCB\@}}}}(T)]\leq\mathcal{O}% \Bigg{(}\underbrace{\sum_{j=1}^{\Upsilon}\frac{v^{\frac{1}{\epsilon}}\log(T)}{% {(\widetilde{\delta}_{min}^{(j)})}^{\frac{1+\epsilon}{\epsilon}}}\left\lceil% \frac{K}{\eta}\right\rceil\Delta_{max}^{(j)}}_{\text{\emph{{\color[rgb]{0,0,1}% \definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,1}(A) Detection Delay % Contribution}}}}+\underbrace{\sum_{j=1}^{\Upsilon}\mathbb{E}[R^{{\pi_{s}}}(|E_% {j}|)]}_{\text{\emph{{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{% rgb}{1,0,0}(B) Stationary Policy Regret}}}}+\underbrace{\eta\sum_{j=1}^{% \Upsilon}|E_{j}|\Delta_{max}^{(j)}}_{\text{\emph{{\color[rgb]{0,0.5,0}% \definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0.5,0}(C) Uniform Exploration}}}}% \Bigg{)}.blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT R-CPD-UCB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) ] â‰¤ caligraphic_O ( underâŸ start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( italic_T ) end_ARG start_ARG ( over~ start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG âŒˆ divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î· end_ARG âŒ‰ roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( typewriter_A ) Detection Delay Contribution end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + underâŸ start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( | italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ) ] end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( typewriter_B ) Stationary Policy Regret end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + underâŸ start_ARG italic_Î· âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( typewriter_C ) Uniform Exploration end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (6)

The regret can be decomposed into three contributions due to: the detection delay (part (A)), the regret-per-epoch of the stationary policy (part (B)), and the rounds of uniform exploration (part (C)).

Uniform Exploration Trade-off.Â Â The uniform exploration parameter Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· appears in both (A) and (C). Setting aside part (B), it is clear that Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· creates a trade-off between these two: the larger Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· is, the quicker the algorithm can detect a change, and the smaller is (A); on the other hand, excessive uniform exploration inflates the regret of R-CPD-UCB and the contribution from (C). Finding the optimal value for Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· would require extensive prior knowledge, which is, in general, not available. A good trade-off is to set Î·=Î¥/Tğœ‚Î¥ğ‘‡\eta=\sqrt{\Upsilon/T}italic_Î· = square-root start_ARG roman_Î¥ / italic_T end_ARG, which impose both (A) and (C) to be ğ’ª~â¢(Î¥â¢T)~ğ’ªÎ¥ğ‘‡\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}(\sqrt{\Upsilon T})over~ start_ARG caligraphic_O end_ARG ( square-root start_ARG roman_Î¥ italic_T end_ARG ). However, it is possible to define a forced exploration strategy that does not require any knowledge of Î¥Î¥\Upsilonroman_Î¥, making the algorithm more versatile while keeping the same order of performance. In particular, we can leverage the methodology developed in besson2022efficient and obtain the following result.

Corollary 4.9.

Let {Î·j}jâˆˆâ„•subscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘—ğ‘—â„•\{\eta_{j}\}_{j\in\mathbb{N}}{ italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j âˆˆ blackboard_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where Î·j=Î·0â¢jâ¢Kâ¢logâ¡(T)/Tsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘—subscriptğœ‚0ğ‘—ğ¾ğ‘‡ğ‘‡\eta_{j}=\eta_{0}\sqrt{jK\log(T)/T}italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT square-root start_ARG italic_j italic_K roman_log ( italic_T ) / italic_T end_ARG for some Î·0>0subscriptğœ‚00\eta_{0}>0italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 be an increasing sequence. R-CPD-UCB using Î·j+1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘—1\eta_{j+1}italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT after the jğ‘—jitalic_j-th detection satisfies:

(A) â‰¤v1Ïµâ¢Kâ¢Î¥â¢Tâ¢logâ¡(T)Î·0â¢Î´mâ¢iâ¢n1+ÏµÏµâ¢Î”mâ¢aâ¢x,(C)â‰¤Î·0â¢Kâ¢(Î¥+1)â¢Tâ¢logâ¡(T)â¢Î”mâ¢aâ¢x.formulae-sequenceabsentsuperscriptğ‘£1italic-Ïµğ¾Î¥ğ‘‡ğ‘‡subscriptğœ‚0superscriptsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›1italic-Ïµitalic-ÏµsubscriptÎ”ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥(C)subscriptğœ‚0ğ¾Î¥1ğ‘‡ğ‘‡subscriptÎ”ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥\displaystyle\leq\frac{v^{\frac{1}{\epsilon}}\sqrt{K\Upsilon T\log(T)}}{\eta_{% 0}{{\delta}_{min}}^{\frac{1+\epsilon}{\epsilon}}}\Delta_{max},\qquad\text{{% \color[rgb]{0,0.5,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0.5,0}(C)}}\leq% \eta_{0}\sqrt{K(\Upsilon+1)T\log(T)}\Delta_{max}.â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT square-root start_ARG italic_K roman_Î¥ italic_T roman_log ( italic_T ) end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (C) â‰¤ italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT square-root start_ARG italic_K ( roman_Î¥ + 1 ) italic_T roman_log ( italic_T ) end_ARG roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (7)

Note that, if Î´mâ¢iâ¢nsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›{\delta}_{min}italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is known, setting Î·0=Î´mâ¢iâ¢nâˆ’1+Ïµ2â¢Ïµsubscriptğœ‚0superscriptsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›1italic-Ïµ2italic-Ïµ\eta_{0}=\delta_{min}^{-\frac{1+\epsilon}{2\epsilon}}italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can further reduce the regret bound.

Choosing Ï€ssubscriptğœ‹ğ‘ \pi_{s}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.Â Â  The choice of the inner regret minimizer Ï€ssubscriptğœ‹ğ‘ \pi_{s}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT determines the magnitude of part (B). The best choice is to select a policy that has a regret upper bound matching the known lower bound of Î©â¢(KÏµ1+Ïµâ¢T11+Ïµ)Î©superscriptğ¾italic-Ïµ1italic-Ïµsuperscriptğ‘‡11italic-Ïµ\Omega(K^{\frac{\epsilon}{1+\epsilon}}T^{\frac{1}{1+\epsilon}})roman_Î© ( italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). We can instantiate R-CPD-UCB using the Robust UCB policy with median-of-means estimator from (bubeck2013bandits, , Section 2.2). As a result, we get the following bounds.

Corollary 4.10.

Let Ï€ssubscriptğœ‹ğ‘ \pi_{s}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the Robust UCB policy with median-of-means estimator (bubeck2013bandits, , Section 2.2). Under Assumption 4.7, R-CPD-UCB suffers an expected cumulative regret bounded as:

ğ”¼[\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[blackboard_E [ RÏ€R-CPD-UCB(T)]â‰¤ğ’ª((A)+âŸâˆ‘j=1Î¥âˆ‘i:Î”i(j)>0v1Ïµlog(|Ej|)(Î”i(j))1Ïµ(B1) Robust UCB Regret (Instance Dependent) +Â (C)).\displaystyle R^{\pi^{\text{\emph{R-CPD-UCB\@}}}}(T)]\leq\mathcal{O}\Bigg{(}% \text{\emph{{\color[rgb]{0,0,1}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,1}% (A)}}}+\underbrace{\sum_{j=1}^{\Upsilon}\sum_{i:\Delta_{i}^{(j)}>0}\frac{v^{% \frac{1}{\epsilon}}\log\left(|E_{j}|\right)}{(\Delta_{i}^{(j)})^{\frac{1}{% \epsilon}}}}_{{\text{\makebox[0.0pt]{\emph{{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}\definecolor[% named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{1,0,0}(B${}_{1}$) Robust UCB Regret}} \text{\emph{% {\color[rgb]{1,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{1,0,0}(Instance % Dependent)}}} }}}}+\text{ \emph{{\color[rgb]{0,0.5,0}\definecolor[named]{% pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0.5,0}(C)}}}\Bigg{)}.italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT R-CPD-UCB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) ] â‰¤ caligraphic_O ( (A) + underâŸ start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i : roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( | italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ) end_ARG start_ARG ( roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT (B1) Robust UCB Regret italic_(Instance italic_Dependent) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_(C)). (8)

Moreover, if logâ¡(|Ej|)â‰¥5â¢(Î”mâ¢aâ¢x(j))1+ÏµÏµ2â¢v1Ïµsubscriptğ¸ğ‘—5superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘—1italic-Ïµitalic-Ïµ2superscriptğ‘£1italic-Ïµ\log(|E_{j}|)\geq\frac{5(\Delta_{max}^{(j)})^{\frac{1+\epsilon}{\epsilon}}}{2v% ^{\frac{1}{\epsilon}}}roman_log ( | italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ) â‰¥ divide start_ARG 5 ( roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG for every jâˆˆ[Î¥]ğ‘—delimited-[]Î¥j\in[\Upsilon]italic_j âˆˆ [ roman_Î¥ ], we have:

ğ”¼[RÏ€R-CPD-UCB(T)]â‰¤ğ’ª~((A)+âŸ|(KÎ¥)Ïµ1+Ïµ(vT)11+Ïµ(B2) Robust UCB Regret (Instance Independent) +Â (C)).\mathbb{E}[R^{\pi^{\text{\emph{R-CPD-UCB\@}}}}(T)]\leq\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}(% \text{\emph{{\color[rgb]{0,0,1}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,1}% (A)}}}+\underbrace{{\color[rgb]{1,1,1}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}% {1,1,1}\pgfsys@color@gray@stroke{1}\pgfsys@color@gray@fill{1}\Bigg{|}}(K% \Upsilon)^{\frac{\epsilon}{1+\epsilon}}(vT)^{\frac{1}{1+\epsilon}}}_{{\text{% \makebox[0.0pt]{\emph{{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{% rgb}{1,0,0}(B${}_{2}$) Robust UCB Regret}} \text{\emph{{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}% \definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{1,0,0}(Instance Independent)}}} }}}}+% \text{ \emph{{\color[rgb]{0,0.5,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{% 0,0.5,0}(C)}}}).blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT typewriter_R-CPD-UCB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) ] â‰¤ over~ start_ARG caligraphic_O end_ARG ( (A) + underâŸ start_ARG | ( italic_K roman_Î¥ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_v italic_T ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT (B2) Robust UCB Regret italic_(Instance italic_Independent) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_(C)). (9)

Equation (8) is a direct consequence of Theorem 4.8 and Theorem 3 of bubeck2013bandits . Equation (9) follows from Theorem 4.8, Proposition 1 of bubeck2013bandits , and Jensenâ€™s inequality. Robust UCB enjoys both instance-dependent and instance-independent guarantees: part (B1) depends on the sub-optimality gaps Î”i(j)superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘—\Delta_{i}^{(j)}roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the individual lengths of the epochs, while part (B2) does not, as it accounts for a worst-case scenario of the sub-optimality gaps. We can now combine all and get the following.

Corollary 4.11.

Let Ï€ssubscriptğœ‹ğ‘ \pi_{s}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the Robust UCB policy with median-of-means estimator from (bubeck2013bandits, , Section 2.2). Let {Î·j}jâˆˆâ„•subscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘—ğ‘—â„•\{\eta_{j}\}_{j\in\mathbb{N}}{ italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j âˆˆ blackboard_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where Î·j=Î·0â¢jâ¢Kâ¢logâ¡(T)/Tsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘—subscriptğœ‚0ğ‘—ğ¾ğ‘‡ğ‘‡\eta_{j}=\eta_{0}\sqrt{jK\log(T)/T}italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT square-root start_ARG italic_j italic_K roman_log ( italic_T ) / italic_T end_ARG for some Î·0>0subscriptğœ‚00\eta_{0}>0italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0. Under Assumption 4.7, R-CPD-UCB using Î·j+1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘—1\eta_{j+1}italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT after the jğ‘—jitalic_j-th detection suffers an expected cumulative regret bounded as:

ğ”¼[\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[blackboard_E [ RÏ€R-CPD-UCB(T)]â‰¤ğ’ª(v1Ïµâ¢Kâ¢Î¥â¢Tâ¢logâ¡(T)Î·0â¢Î´mâ¢iâ¢n1+ÏµÏµÎ”mâ¢aâ¢x+Kâ¢Î¥â¢v1Ïµâ¢logâ¡(T/Î¥)Î”mâ¢iâ¢n1Ïµ).\displaystyle R^{\pi^{\text{\emph{R-CPD-UCB\@}}}}(T)]\leq\mathcal{O}\Bigg{(}% \frac{v^{\frac{1}{\epsilon}}\sqrt{K\Upsilon T\log(T)}}{\eta_{0}{{\delta}_{min}% }^{\frac{1+\epsilon}{\epsilon}}}\Delta_{max}+\frac{K\Upsilon v^{\frac{1}{% \epsilon}}\log\left(T/\Upsilon\right)}{\Delta_{min}^{\frac{1}{\epsilon}}}\Bigg% {)}.italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT R-CPD-UCB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) ] â‰¤ caligraphic_O ( divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT square-root start_ARG italic_K roman_Î¥ italic_T roman_log ( italic_T ) end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG italic_K roman_Î¥ italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( italic_T / roman_Î¥ ) end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) . (10)
