Moreover, if logâ¡(|Ej|)â‰¥3â¢(Î”mâ¢aâ¢x(j))1+ÏµÏµâ¢vâˆ’1Ïµsubscriptğ¸ğ‘—3superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘—1italic-Ïµitalic-Ïµsuperscriptğ‘£1italic-Ïµ\log(|E_{j}|)\geq 3(\Delta_{max}^{(j)})^{\frac{1+\epsilon}{\epsilon}}v^{-\frac% {1}{\epsilon}}roman_log ( | italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ) â‰¥ 3 ( roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for every jâˆˆ[Î¥]ğ‘—delimited-[]Î¥j\in[\Upsilon]italic_j âˆˆ [ roman_Î¥ ], and Î´mâ¢iâ¢n1+ÏµÏµâ‰¥v1Ïµâ¢(1+Ïµ)â¢(Î¥â¢K/T)1âˆ’Ïµ2â¢(1+Ïµ)â¢logâ¡(T)superscriptsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›1italic-Ïµitalic-Ïµsuperscriptğ‘£1italic-Ïµ1italic-ÏµsuperscriptÎ¥ğ¾ğ‘‡1italic-Ïµ21italic-Ïµğ‘‡\delta_{min}^{\frac{1+\epsilon}{\epsilon}}\geq v^{\frac{1}{\epsilon(1+\epsilon% )}}(\Upsilon K/T)^{\frac{1-\epsilon}{2(1+\epsilon)}}\sqrt{\log(T)}italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ ( 1 + italic_Ïµ ) end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_Î¥ italic_K / italic_T ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 - italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 2 ( 1 + italic_Ïµ ) end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT square-root start_ARG roman_log ( italic_T ) end_ARG, we have:

ğ”¼[RÏ€R-CPD-UCB(T)]â‰¤ğ’ª~(|(KÎ¥)Ïµ1+Ïµ(vT)11+Ïµ).\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[R^{\pi^{\text{\emph{R-CPD-UCB\@}}}}(T)]\leq\widetilde{% \mathcal{O}}({\color[rgb]{1,1,1}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{1,1,1% }\pgfsys@color@gray@stroke{1}\pgfsys@color@gray@fill{1}\Bigg{|}}(K\Upsilon)^{% \frac{\epsilon}{1+\epsilon}}(vT)^{\frac{1}{1+\epsilon}}).blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT R-CPD-UCB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) ] â‰¤ over~ start_ARG caligraphic_O end_ARG ( | ( italic_K roman_Î¥ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_v italic_T ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (11)

Equation (10), depends on both the minimum mean change Î´mâ¢iâ¢nsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›\delta_{min}italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the extreme sub-optimality gaps Î”mâ¢iâ¢nsubscriptÎ”ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›\Delta_{min}roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Î”mâ¢aâ¢xsubscriptÎ”ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥\Delta_{max}roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, along the whole trial. We consider this bound an instance-dependent guarantee over the performance of R-CPD-UCB. Equation (11), instead, does not contain any of these quantities. The second assumption fundamentally states that Î´mâ¢iâ¢nsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›\delta_{min}italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be assumed to be a constant w.r.t. the other quantities, in particular Tğ‘‡Titalic_T. In this case, an instance-independent bound can be obtained. Equation (11) matches, up to constants, the lower bound presented in Theorem 2.5. Thus, if we focus on the dependence on Tğ‘‡Titalic_T, Î¥Î¥\Upsilonroman_Î¥, vğ‘£vitalic_v, and Kğ¾Kitalic_K the performance guarantees of R-CPD-UCB are nearly-optimal.

5 Numerical Evaluation

We now provide a numerical evaluation of Robust-CPD-UCB (Ï€ssubscriptğœ‹ğ‘ \pi_{s}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT chosen as Robust UCB with median-of-means estimator). We refer to Appendix C for additional details and experimental campaigns.

5.1 Casting Real-World Data to HTPS MABs

We model a real-world scenario as an HTPS MAB and, then, we leverage a real dataset to generate an HTPS MAB instance on which R-CPD-UCB is tested. Â Setting.Â Â We consider the problem of profit maximization in financial trading. As pointed out by panahi2016model , financial data exhibit heavy tails. A financial application of HT MABs is identifying the most profitable cryptocurrency among Kğ¾Kitalic_K options. In fact, at the start of each day, an investor would like to invest a share of their money in the cryptocurrency with the highest closing price. This very same application has been studied, for example, in yu2018pure and lee2022minimax , both in the context of HT MABs. We use the same dataset (Kaggle link) employed in lee2022minimax . In Figure 1, we report the closing prices of four selected currencies among the top ten by market capitalization, along with a piecewise-constant fit of the data that minimizes the squared error. We observe two things: first, the piecewise constant approximation is a better fit than any constant approximation (in the previous works on HT MABs, the reward from a given currency was always considered stationary); second, this approximation suffers a high error in certain segments where the stochastic fluctuations are really strong. Following the existing literature panahi2016model , we fit the price distribution inside every segment with a Pareto distribution having its mean centered on the segment height, using Ïµ<1italic-Ïµ1\epsilon<1italic_Ïµ < 1 and v=3ğ‘£3v=3italic_v = 3. Thus, the profit maximization problem in cryptocurrency trading can be treated as an HTPS MAB. Â Results.Â Â Starting from the piecewise-constant fit of the prices, we can build an HTPS MAB environment on which we test R-CPD-UCB, together with Sliding Window UCB garivier2011upper and MR-APE lee2022minimax , which was already tested on the same dataset when assuming stationarity. In Figure 2, we report the cumulative regrets obtained by the three algorithms averaged over 20202020 trials (xğ‘¥xitalic_x-axis is rescaled). R-CPD-UCB performs better than the two competitors, as it is the only algorithm tackling both heavy-tailedness and non-stationarity of the setting.

5.2 Regret Minimization in Highly Non-Stationary Environments

We now evaluate how R-CPD-UCB behaves in highly dynamic scenarios where changes are close.
Setting.Â Â We compare R-CPD-UCB with two of the most popular algorithms from the literature, Monitored UCB cao2019nearly and Sliding Window UCB garivier2011upper . We consider two PS MABs: Gaussian rewards with Ïƒ=1ğœ1\sigma=1italic_Ïƒ = 1 and Pareto rewards with Ïµ<12italic-Ïµ12\epsilon<\frac{1}{2}italic_Ïµ < divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG. In both MABs, we have K=3ğ¾3K=3italic_K = 3, T=1500ğ‘‡1500T=1500italic_T = 1500 and Î¥=6Î¥6\Upsilon=6roman_Î¥ = 6. Also, we have Î´mâ¢iâ¢n=0subscriptğ›¿ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›0\delta_{min}=0italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, i.e., and some actions may not change their means after a change point. However, at least one arm has its mean change, and the optimal action changes at least 4444 times. Interestingly, these instances violate Assumption 4.7. Â Results.Â Â In Figure 5, we report the cumulative regrets suffered by the considered algorithms. R-CPD-UCB achieves, in both instances, a smaller cumulative regret than competitors. Moreover, it shows a smaller uncertainty and more stable performances across the trials, especially when rewards have infinite variance (Figure 5(b)). Interestingly, R-CPD-UCB can outperform both Monitored UCB and Sliding Window UCB even when the rewards are Gaussian. This is because the change points are frequent and very close. Robust mean estimation using median-of-means stabilizes the algorithmâ€™s behavior in data-scarce regimes. Finally, we remark that Assumption 4.7 is violated by these two instances; however, R-CPD-UCB performs well (and so is Monitored UCB, which relies on a similar hypothesis). This phenomenon was already observed in cao2019nearly , and shows how Assumption 4.7, in practice, is not very limiting.

6 Conclusions

In this work, we provided the first study on regret minimization in heavy-tailed piecewise-stationary bandits. We provided a lower bound on the performance of every algorithm and proposed Robust-CPD-UCB, a novel algorithm whose regret nearly matches the lower bound. We leverage novel advancements in the theory of change-point detection, building Catoni-FCS-detector, a general detection strategy suited for distributions with infinite variance. Finally, numerical evaluation shows that the performance of R-CPD-UCB is solid when compared to existing baselines. An interesting future direction would be to study the HTPS MAB problem when vğ‘£vitalic_v and Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ are unknown.

Appendix A Additional Related Works on Non-Stationary MABs

In this appendix, we discuss more in detail the related works on non-stationary MABs.

A.1 Piecewise-Stationary MABs

The most common definition of piecewise-stationary MABs in the literature is the one introduced by [29]. In this work, the authors deal with the PS MAB problem as it is defined in this work, and consider both a scenario in which side-observations are available, and an agnostic scenario in which they are not, which corresponds to the one that we study in this work. In the latter scenario, they show that every algorithm must suffer at least Î©â¢(T)Î©ğ‘‡\Omega(\sqrt{T})roman_Î© ( square-root start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ) regret. In [11], the authors analyze two algorithms to tackle the PS MAB problem, namely Discounted UCB (introduced in [17]) and Sliding Window UCB. Contrary to ours, these algorithms donâ€™t rely on any CPD strategy but rather passively adapt to the changes in the environment. In practice, actively adapting algorithm, e.g., algorithm based on CPD strategies like ours, hence show better performances. The idea of actively adapt to changes first appeared in [14]. More recent works, such as [20] and [8], paved the way for the analysis of actively adaptive algorithms, which were considered tougher to analyze from a theoretical perspective w.r.t. to their passive counterparts. Recently, with [2] and [4], there has been focus on removing the prior knowledge on Î¥Î¥\Upsilonroman_Î¥ from the algorithms. In the former, the AdSwitch algorithm they propose does not require any additional assumptions, but it is not optimized for tractability or numerical efficiency. Indeed, as shown in [4], AdSwitch enjoys poor empirical performance. In the latter, the authors propose an algorithm that performs well in practice and has tight theoretical guarantees without any need for Î¥Î¥\Upsilonroman_Î¥ to be known beforehand, however they rely on an assumption which is nearly the same as ours. All of the aforementioned works donâ€™t account for the heavy-tailed setting, as their scope is restricted to rewards with bounded support or sub-gaussian. The only work that accounts for non-stationarity in heavy-tailed settings is [5], where the authors consider a general framework to allow for more general risk measures (linear being the case considered here), and consider the same setup of piecewise-stationary bandits and heavy-tailed rewards, and establish upper and lower bounds on the regret under special assumptions on the risk measures and distributions. However, there are multiple reasons for why our approach is better suited in the regret-minimization scenario:

  • â€¢

    Assumption 1 (Stability): since their paper focuses on achieving strong regret guarantees with heavy-tailed rewards, the stability assumption plays a crucial role in the analysis, where the rate functions on the decay of the empirical and truncated distributions are assumed to be known. While the assumption is not strong in and of itself, the knowledge of these parameters play a crucial role in the change detection and regret minimization procedures, and also appear in the regret bounds. Robust-CPD-UCB, on the other hand, requires no knowledge of such functions, relies on novel analysis of Catoni estimators that do not necessitate truncations, and is simpler to run online in practice.

  • â€¢

    The CPD routine used in [5] is based on a sliding window method requiring specification of both widow size and threshold. Robust-CPD-UCB is based on the newly developed CPD method based on Catoni estimator that runs online only with the same assumption on the distributions.

  • â€¢

    The regret minimization algorithm in [5] uses a data-driven truncation of the rewards that depends on the policy, and the knowledge of the decay rate functions to compute the exploration bias for the arm index. Our work, on the other hand, requires no such methods and uses a simple combination of the novel Catoni-CPD and any policy suited for the stationary heavy-tailed regret minimization.

For the most common case of linear risk/ regret in mean, Robust-CPD-UCB establishes stronger guarantees with the CPD procedure requiring weaker assumptions. Finally, it is easier to implement owing to not requiring distributional knowledge or thresholds.

A.2 Bounded Variation and Monotonically Non-stationary MABs

Another setting of interest is non-stationary MABs with bounded variations. In this setting, the rewardsâ€™ distributions changes are less restricted, and the focus moves from the number of changes to the total amount of change VTsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘‡V_{T}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In [3], the authors propose Rexp3, an algorithm that leverages tools from the adversarial MAB problem to deal with non-stationarity in stochastic settings. The regret upper bound that they provide is in the order of ğ’ªâ¢(VT13â¢T23)ğ’ªsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘‡13superscriptğ‘‡23\mathcal{O}(V_{T}^{\frac{1}{3}}T^{\frac{2}{3}})caligraphic_O ( italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Over the last years, there has been increasing interest in monotonically non-stationary MABs, i.e., non-stationary MABs where the mean rewards are only allowed to decrease (rotting bandits, [24, 25]) or to increase (rising bandits, [22]), some works focus on both settings [15, 13]. The monotonicity assumptions substitutes the need for piecewise-stationarity, as it is a strong enough assumption to allow for strong theoretical characterizations. In such settings, regret bounds depend in general on the total variation of the distributionsâ€™ means and instance-dependent-type of results are common in this literature. Moreover, the additional structure added by this assumption, put the accent on the difference between restless bandits (a proper non-stationary setting) and rested bandits, where the evolution of rewards depends on learnerâ€™s actions rather than just time.

Appendix B Proofs

See 2.5

Proof.

The proof of this theorem combines techniques from Lemma 5 of [25], Theorem 4 of [12], and Theorem 6 from [10].

Consider the following prototype of reward distribution, defined for yâˆˆ(0,1)ğ‘¦01y\in\left(0,1\right)italic_y âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ) and Î”âˆˆ(0,1)Î”01\Delta\in\left(0,1\right)roman_Î” âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ):

Ïy=(1âˆ’vâˆ’1Ïµâ¢y1+ÏµÏµ)â¢Î´0+(vâˆ’1Ïµâ¢y1+ÏµÏµ)â¢Î´v1Ïµâ¢Î”âˆ’1Ïµ.subscriptğœŒğ‘¦1superscriptğ‘£1italic-Ïµsuperscriptğ‘¦1italic-Ïµitalic-Ïµsubscriptğ›¿0superscriptğ‘£1italic-Ïµsuperscriptğ‘¦1italic-Ïµitalic-Ïµsubscriptğ›¿superscriptğ‘£1italic-ÏµsuperscriptÎ”1italic-Ïµ\rho_{y}=\left(1-v^{-\frac{1}{\epsilon}}y^{\frac{1+\epsilon}{\epsilon}}\right)% \delta_{0}+\left(v^{-\frac{1}{\epsilon}}y^{\frac{1+\epsilon}{\epsilon}}\right)% \delta_{v^{\frac{1}{\epsilon}}\Delta^{-\frac{1}{\epsilon}}}.italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 - italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

It is easy to verify that Ïyâˆˆâ„‹(1,Ïµ)subscriptğœŒğ‘¦subscriptâ„‹1italic-Ïµ\rho_{y}\in\mathcal{H}_{(1,\epsilon)}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 , italic_Ïµ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for every yâˆˆ[0,Î”]ğ‘¦0Î”y\in[0,\Delta]italic_y âˆˆ [ 0 , roman_Î” ].

Consider a set of of instances belonging to â„¬(v,Ïµ,Î¥)subscriptâ„¬ğ‘£italic-ÏµÎ¥\mathcal{B}_{(v,\epsilon,\Upsilon)}caligraphic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v , italic_Ïµ , roman_Î¥ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT indexed by a vector ğ’Šâˆ—âˆˆ[K]Î¥superscriptğ’Šsuperscriptdelimited-[]ğ¾Î¥\bm{i}^{*}\in[K]^{\Upsilon}bold_italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ [ italic_K ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in a way that, for every jâˆˆ[Î¥]ğ‘—delimited-[]Î¥j\in[\Upsilon]italic_j âˆˆ [ roman_Î¥ ] and every tâˆˆEjğ‘¡subscriptğ¸ğ‘—t\in E_{j}italic_t âˆˆ italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we have

Î½i(j)={Ï2Ïµ1+Ïµâ¢Î”,ifâ¢i=ijâˆ—ÏÎ”,ifâ¢iâ‰ ijâˆ—.superscriptsubscriptğœˆğ‘–ğ‘—casessubscriptğœŒsuperscript2italic-Ïµ1italic-ÏµÎ”ifğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğœŒÎ”ifğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘—\nu_{i}^{(j)}=\begin{cases}\rho_{2^{\frac{\epsilon}{1+\epsilon}}\Delta},~{}~{}% ~{}&\text{if}~{}i=i_{j}^{*}\\ \rho_{\Delta},~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}&\text{if}~{}i\neq i_{j}^{*}\\ \end{cases}\,.italic_Î½ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { start_ROW start_CELL italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL start_CELL if italic_i = italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î” end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL start_CELL if italic_i â‰  italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW .

It follows that Î¼ijâˆ—(j)âˆ’Î¼i(j)=Î”superscriptsubscriptğœ‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ‘—Î”\mu_{i_{j}^{*}}^{(j)}-\mu_{i}^{(j)}=\Deltaitalic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_Î” for every jâˆˆ[Î¥]ğ‘—delimited-[]Î¥j\in[\Upsilon]italic_j âˆˆ [ roman_Î¥ ] and iâ‰ ijâˆ—ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘—i\neq i_{j}^{*}italic_i â‰  italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Let |Ej|=TÎ¥subscriptğ¸ğ‘—ğ‘‡Î¥|E_{j}|=\frac{T}{\Upsilon}| italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | = divide start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î¥ end_ARG for every jâˆˆ[Î¥]ğ‘—delimited-[]Î¥j\in[\Upsilon]italic_j âˆˆ [ roman_Î¥ ], assuming w.l.o.g. that Tğ‘‡Titalic_T is divisible by Î¥Î¥\Upsilonroman_Î¥. â‰¤logâ¡(2)2â¢Kâ¢|Ej|â¢vâˆ’1Ïµâ¢Î”1+ÏµÏµ,absent22ğ¾subscriptğ¸ğ‘—superscriptğ‘£1italic-ÏµsuperscriptÎ”1italic-Ïµitalic-Ïµ\displaystyle\leq\frac{\log(2)}{2K}|E_{j}|v^{-\frac{1}{\epsilon}}\Delta^{\frac% {1+\epsilon}{\epsilon}},â‰¤ divide start_ARG roman_log ( 2 ) end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_K end_ARG | italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

that implies

1Kâ¢âˆ‘i=1Kğ”¼(ğ’Šâˆ’jâˆ—,i)â¢[Ni(j)]â‰¤|Ej|K+logâ¡(2)2â¢Kâ¢|Ej|32â¢vâˆ’12â¢Ïµâ¢Î”1+Ïµ2â¢Ïµ.1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ¾subscriptğ”¼superscriptsubscriptğ’Šğ‘—ğ‘–delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ¸ğ‘—ğ¾22ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ¸ğ‘—32superscriptğ‘£12italic-ÏµsuperscriptÎ”1italic-Ïµ2italic-Ïµ\displaystyle\frac{1}{K}\sum_{i=1}^{K}\mathbb{E}_{(\bm{i}_{-j}^{*},i)}\left[N_% {i}^{(j)}\right]\leq\frac{|E_{j}|}{K}+\sqrt{\frac{\log(2)}{2K}}|E_{j}|^{\frac{% 3}{2}}v^{-\frac{1}{2\epsilon}}\Delta^{\frac{1+\epsilon}{2\epsilon}}.divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_i ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ divide start_ARG | italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG + square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG roman_log ( 2 ) end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_K end_ARG end_ARG | italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (13)

Combining Equation (12) and Equation (13), we get

1KÎ¥â¢âˆ‘ğ’Šâˆ—âˆˆ[K]Î¥ğ”¼ğ’Šâˆ—â¢[RÏ€â¢(T)]1superscriptğ¾Î¥subscriptsuperscriptğ’Šsuperscriptdelimited-[]ğ¾Î¥subscriptğ”¼superscriptğ’Šdelimited-[]superscriptğ‘…ğœ‹ğ‘‡\displaystyle\frac{1}{K^{\Upsilon}}\sum_{\bm{i}^{*}\in[K]^{\Upsilon}}\mathbb{E% }_{\bm{i}^{*}}\left[R^{\pi}(T)\right]divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ [ italic_K ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) ] â‰¥(T2âˆ’âˆ‘k=1Î¥logâ¡(2)2â¢Kâ¢|Ej|32â¢vâˆ’12â¢Ïµâ¢Î”1+Ïµ2â¢Ïµ)â¢Î”absentğ‘‡2superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1Î¥22ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ¸ğ‘—32superscriptğ‘£12italic-ÏµsuperscriptÎ”1italic-Ïµ2italic-ÏµÎ”\displaystyle\geq\left(\frac{T}{2}-\sum_{k=1}^{\Upsilon}\sqrt{\frac{\log(2)}{2% K}}|E_{j}|^{\frac{3}{2}}v^{-\frac{1}{2\epsilon}}\Delta^{\frac{1+\epsilon}{2% \epsilon}}\right)\Deltaâ‰¥ ( divide start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG - âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG roman_log ( 2 ) end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_K end_ARG end_ARG | italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) roman_Î”
â‰¥12â¢(2â¢logâ¡(2)16)Ïµ1+Ïµâ¢KÏµ1+Ïµâ¢Î¥Ïµ1+Ïµâ¢T11+Ïµ,absent12superscript2216italic-Ïµ1italic-Ïµsuperscriptğ¾italic-Ïµ1italic-ÏµsuperscriptÎ¥italic-Ïµ1italic-Ïµsuperscriptğ‘‡11italic-Ïµ\displaystyle\geq\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{2\log(2)}{16}\right)^{\frac{\epsilon}{% 1+\epsilon}}K^{\frac{\epsilon}{1+\epsilon}}\Upsilon^{\frac{\epsilon}{1+% \epsilon}}T^{\frac{1}{1+\epsilon}},â‰¥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 2 roman_log ( 2 ) end_ARG start_ARG 16 end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

by setting Î”=v11+Ïµâ¢(2â¢logâ¡(2)â¢Kâ¢Î¥16â¢T)Ïµ1+ÏµÎ”superscriptğ‘£11italic-Ïµsuperscript22ğ¾Î¥16ğ‘‡italic-Ïµ1italic-Ïµ\Delta=v^{\frac{1}{1+\epsilon}}\left(\frac{2\log(2)K\Upsilon}{16T}\right)^{% \frac{\epsilon}{1+\epsilon}}roman_Î” = italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG 2 roman_log ( 2 ) italic_K roman_Î¥ end_ARG start_ARG 16 italic_T end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. âˆ

Remark B.1.

In the proof of Theorem 2.5, we do not impose any condition on Tğ‘‡Titalic_T. Moreover, the length of every epoch is equal to T/Î¥ğ‘‡Î¥T/\Upsilonitalic_T / roman_Î¥. This means that in principle one can choose a large enough Tğ‘‡Titalic_T, i.e., Tâ‰¥2â¢Î¥â¢âŒˆLjâ¢KÎ·âŒ‰ğ‘‡2Î¥subscriptğ¿ğ‘—ğ¾ğœ‚T\geq 2\Upsilon\lceil L_{j}\frac{K}{\eta}\rceilitalic_T â‰¥ 2 roman_Î¥ âŒˆ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î· end_ARG âŒ‰, such that Assumption 4.7 holds. This proves that our assumption does not make the problem easier from a regret minimization perspective.

See 4.2

Proof.

Due to its length, we divided this proof into several steps. In Steps 1-3 we extend Theorem 10 of [28] to the case of heavy-tailed random variables. In Step 4 we apply the sticthing technique to the resulting CS, tightening its width. Then, in Step 5 we define the CS hyper-parameters and define a set of good events, under which we are able to properly bound the detection delay in Step 7. The proof is concluded by showing that no false alarm occurs under the good event (Step 8).
Step 1 (Building a nonnegative supermartingale) First, we observe that

Mtsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡\displaystyle M_{t}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰”âˆi=1texpâ¡{Ï•Ïµâ¢(Î»iâ¢(Xiâˆ’Î¼))âˆ’Î»i1+Ïµâ¢v1+Ïµ},â‰”absentsuperscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘¡subscriptitalic-Ï•italic-Ïµsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–ğœ‡superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–1italic-Ïµğ‘£1italic-Ïµ\displaystyle\coloneqq\prod_{i=1}^{t}\exp\left\{\phi_{\epsilon}(\lambda_{i}(X_% {i}-\mu))-\lambda_{i}^{1+\epsilon}\frac{v}{1+\epsilon}\right\},â‰” âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_exp { italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î¼ ) ) - italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 + italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG } ,
Ntsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡\displaystyle N_{t}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰”âˆi=1texpâ¡{âˆ’Ï•Ïµâ¢(Î»iâ¢(Xiâˆ’Î¼))âˆ’Î»i1+Ïµâ¢v1+Ïµ},â‰”absentsuperscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘¡subscriptitalic-Ï•italic-Ïµsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–ğœ‡superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–1italic-Ïµğ‘£1italic-Ïµ\displaystyle\coloneqq\prod_{i=1}^{t}\exp\left\{-\phi_{\epsilon}(\lambda_{i}(X% _{i}-\mu))-\lambda_{i}^{1+\epsilon}\frac{v}{1+\epsilon}\right\},â‰” âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_exp { - italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î¼ ) ) - italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 + italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG } ,

are nonnegative supermartingales. To prove this for Mtsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡M_{t}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (all steps are analogous for Ntsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡N_{t}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), we bound

and, subsequently,

ğ”¼[Mt|â„±tâˆ’1]=Mtâˆ’1ğ”¼[exp{Ï•Ïµ(Î»t(Xtâˆ’Î¼))âˆ’Î»t1+Ïµv1+Ïµ}|â„±tâˆ’1]â‰¤Mtâˆ’1.\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[M_{t}\,\,\bigg{\lvert}\,\mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right]=% M_{t-1}\mathbb{E}\left[\exp\left\{\phi_{\epsilon}(\lambda_{t}(X_{t}-\mu))-% \lambda_{t}^{1+\epsilon}\frac{v}{1+\epsilon}\right\}\,\,\bigg{\lvert}\,% \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right]\leq M_{t-1}.blackboard_E [ italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E [ roman_exp { italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î¼ ) ) - italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 + italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG } | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] â‰¤ italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

which implies

Step 3 (Bounding the width of the CS for Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼) We are now required to provide a bound on the width of the previously derived (1âˆ’Î³)1ğ›¾(1-\gamma)( 1 - italic_Î³ )-CS. For all mâˆˆâ„ğ‘šâ„m\in\mathbb{R}italic_m âˆˆ blackboard_R, let

Mtâ¢(m)=expâ¡{ftâ¢(m)âˆ’âˆ‘i=1t(Î»iâ¢(Î¼âˆ’m)+Î»i1+Ïµ1+Ïµâ¢(v+(Î¼âˆ’m)1+Ïµ))},subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘¡subscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğœ‡ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–1italic-Ïµ1italic-Ïµğ‘£superscriptğœ‡ğ‘š1italic-Ïµ\displaystyle M_{t}(m)=\exp\left\{f_{t}(m)-\sum_{i=1}^{t}\left(\lambda_{i}(\mu% -m)+\frac{\lambda_{i}^{1+\epsilon}}{1+\epsilon}(v+(\mu-m)^{1+\epsilon})\right)% \right\},italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_m ) = roman_exp { italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_m ) - âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î¼ - italic_m ) + divide start_ARG italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 + italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG ( italic_v + ( italic_Î¼ - italic_m ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 + italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) } ,

then, with steps analogous to Step 1, we observe that Mtâ¢(m)subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡ğ‘šM_{t}(m)italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_m ) is a nonnegative supermartingale. Note that Mtâ¢(Î¼)=Mtsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡ğœ‡subscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡M_{t}(\mu)=M_{t}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î¼ ) = italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and an analogous definition leads to the nonnegative supermartingale Ntâ¢(m)subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘šN_{t}(m)italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_m ). We define:

Bt+â¢(m)superscriptsubscriptğµğ‘¡ğ‘š\displaystyle B_{t}^{+}(m)italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) =âˆ‘i=1t(Î»iâ¢(Î¼âˆ’m)+Î»i1+Ïµ1+Ïµâ¢(v+(Î¼âˆ’m)1+Ïµ))+logâ¡(2Î¸)absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘¡subscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğœ‡ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–1italic-Ïµ1italic-Ïµğ‘£superscriptğœ‡ğ‘š1italic-Ïµ2ğœƒ\displaystyle=\sum_{i=1}^{t}\left(\lambda_{i}(\mu-m)+\frac{\lambda_{i}^{1+% \epsilon}}{1+\epsilon}(v+(\mu-m)^{1+\epsilon})\right)+\log\left(\frac{2}{% \theta}\right)= âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î¼ - italic_m ) + divide start_ARG italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 + italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG ( italic_v + ( italic_Î¼ - italic_m ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 + italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) + roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î¸ end_ARG )
Btâˆ’â¢(m)superscriptsubscriptğµğ‘¡ğ‘š\displaystyle B_{t}^{-}(m)italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) =âˆ‘i=1t(Î»iâ¢(Î¼âˆ’m)âˆ’Î»i1+Ïµ1+Ïµâ¢(v+(Î¼âˆ’m)1+Ïµ))âˆ’logâ¡(2Î¸),absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘¡subscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğœ‡ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–1italic-Ïµ1italic-Ïµğ‘£superscriptğœ‡ğ‘š1italic-Ïµ2ğœƒ\displaystyle=\sum_{i=1}^{t}\left(\lambda_{i}(\mu-m)-\frac{\lambda_{i}^{1+% \epsilon}}{1+\epsilon}(v+(\mu-m)^{1+\epsilon})\right)-\log\left(\frac{2}{% \theta}\right),= âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î¼ - italic_m ) - divide start_ARG italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 + italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG ( italic_v + ( italic_Î¼ - italic_m ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 + italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) - roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î¸ end_ARG ) ,

and using Markovâ€™s ineqality we get:

âˆ€mâˆˆâ„,â„™â¢(ftâ¢(m)â‰¤Bt+â¢(m))â‰¥1âˆ’Î¸2formulae-sequencefor-allğ‘šâ„â„™subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğµğ‘¡ğ‘š1ğœƒ2\displaystyle\forall m\in\mathbb{R},~{}~{}~{}\mathbb{P}\left(f_{t}(m)\leq B_{t% }^{+}(m)\right)\geq 1-\frac{\theta}{2}âˆ€ italic_m âˆˆ blackboard_R , blackboard_P ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_m ) â‰¤ italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) ) â‰¥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG
âˆ€mâˆˆâ„,â„™â¢(ftâ¢(m)â‰¥Btâˆ’â¢(m))â‰¥1âˆ’Î¸2.formulae-sequencefor-allğ‘šâ„â„™subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğµğ‘¡ğ‘š1ğœƒ2\displaystyle\forall m\in\mathbb{R},~{}~{}~{}\mathbb{P}\left(f_{t}(m)\geq B_{t% }^{-}(m)\right)\geq 1-\frac{\theta}{2}.âˆ€ italic_m âˆˆ blackboard_R , blackboard_P ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_m ) â‰¥ italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) ) â‰¥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG .

Since Bt+superscriptsubscriptğµğ‘¡B_{t}^{+}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT upper bounds ftâ¢(m)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘šf_{t}(m)italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_m ) with probability at least 1âˆ’Î¸21ğœƒ21-\frac{\theta}{2}1 - divide start_ARG italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG, any m~tsubscript~ğ‘šğ‘¡\widetilde{m}_{t}over~ start_ARG italic_m end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT s.t.

also satisfies

Note that Equation (14) admits solutions if and only if

which yields the upper CS on Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼ in the following form:

â„™â¢(maxâ¡{Câ¢ItÏ•}â‰¤Î¼+âˆ‘i=1t10â¢vâ¢Î»i1+Ïµ+2â¢(1+Ïµ)â¢logâ¡(2Î³)+2â¢(1+Ïµ)â¢logâ¡(2Î¸)âˆ‘i=1tÎ»i)â‰¥1âˆ’Î¸2.â„™ğ¶superscriptsubscriptğ¼ğ‘¡italic-Ï•ğœ‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘¡10ğ‘£superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–1italic-Ïµ21italic-Ïµ2ğ›¾21italic-Ïµ2ğœƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘¡subscriptğœ†ğ‘–1ğœƒ2\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\left(\max\{CI_{t}^{\phi}\}\leq\mu+\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{t}% 10v\lambda_{i}^{1+\epsilon}+2(1+\epsilon)\log\left(\frac{2}{\gamma}\right)+2(1% +\epsilon)\log\left(\frac{2}{\theta}\right)}{\sum_{i=1}^{t}\lambda_{i}}\right)% \geq 1-\frac{\theta}{2}.blackboard_P ( roman_max { italic_C italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï• end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } â‰¤ italic_Î¼ + divide start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 10 italic_v italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 + italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 2 ( 1 + italic_Ïµ ) roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG ) + 2 ( 1 + italic_Ïµ ) roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î¸ end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) â‰¥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG .

Repeating all the previous steps for Btâˆ’â¢(m)superscriptsubscriptğµğ‘¡ğ‘šB_{t}^{-}(m)italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ), and by applying a union bound, yields a two-sided (1âˆ’Î³)1ğ›¾(1-\gamma)( 1 - italic_Î³ )-CS for Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼. The width wâ¢(t,Î¼,Î³)=maxâ¡{Câ¢ItÏ•}âˆ’minâ¡{Câ¢ItÏ•}ğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğœ‡ğ›¾ğ¶superscriptsubscriptğ¼ğ‘¡italic-Ï•ğ¶superscriptsubscriptğ¼ğ‘¡italic-Ï•w(t,\mu,\gamma)=\max\{CI_{t}^{\phi}\}-\min\{CI_{t}^{\phi}\}italic_w ( italic_t , italic_Î¼ , italic_Î³ ) = roman_max { italic_C italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï• end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } - roman_min { italic_C italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï• end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } of such CS concentrates as

â„™â¢(wâ¢(t,Î¼,Î³)â‰¤2â¢âˆ‘i=1t10â¢vâ¢Î»i1+Ïµ+2â¢(1+Ïµ)â¢logâ¡(2Î³)+2â¢(1+Ïµ)â¢logâ¡(2Î¸)âˆ‘i=1tÎ»i)â‰¥1âˆ’Î¸.â„™ğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğœ‡ğ›¾2superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘¡10ğ‘£superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–1italic-Ïµ21italic-Ïµ2ğ›¾21italic-Ïµ2ğœƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘¡subscriptğœ†ğ‘–1ğœƒ\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\left(w(t,\mu,\gamma)\leq 2\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{t}10v% \lambda_{i}^{1+\epsilon}+2(1+\epsilon)\log\left(\frac{2}{\gamma}\right)+2(1+% \epsilon)\log\left(\frac{2}{\theta}\right)}{\sum_{i=1}^{t}\lambda_{i}}\right)% \geq 1-\theta.blackboard_P ( italic_w ( italic_t , italic_Î¼ , italic_Î³ ) â‰¤ 2 divide start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 10 italic_v italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 + italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 2 ( 1 + italic_Ïµ ) roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG ) + 2 ( 1 + italic_Ïµ ) roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î¸ end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) â‰¥ 1 - italic_Î¸ . (17)

Step 4 (Stitching) We now discuss the choice of the sequence {Î»t}tâ‰¥1subscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘¡ğ‘¡1\{\lambda_{t}\}_{t\geq 1}{ italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t â‰¥ 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The idea is to partition time in an exponential grid, and then fix the same value of Î»tsubscriptğœ†ğ‘¡\lambda_{t}italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT inside the same cell. Moreover, the confidence level is modified and set to a cell-specific value Î³jsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘—\gamma_{j}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This idea, called stitching, first appeared in [16]. In particular, set tj=ejsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—superscriptğ‘’ğ‘—t_{j}=e^{j}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, Î³j=Î³(j+1)2subscriptğ›¾ğ‘—ğ›¾superscriptğ‘—12\gamma_{j}=\frac{\gamma}{(j+1)^{2}}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_j + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG, and Î›j=(logâ¡(2Î³j)â¢eâˆ’jâ¢vâˆ’1)11+ÏµsubscriptÎ›ğ‘—superscript2subscriptğ›¾ğ‘—superscriptğ‘’ğ‘—superscriptğ‘£111italic-Ïµ\Lambda_{j}=\left(\log\left(\frac{2}{\gamma_{j}}\right)e^{-j}v^{-1}\right)^{% \frac{1}{1+\epsilon}}roman_Î› start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, for every tj<tâ‰¤tj+1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—1t_{j}<t\leq t_{j+1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_t â‰¤ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we set Î»i=Î›jsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–subscriptÎ›ğ‘—\lambda_{i}=\Lambda_{j}italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_Î› start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for every iâˆˆ[t]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘¡i\in[t]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_t ]. Assume Î¸=Î³4ğœƒğ›¾4\theta=\frac{\gamma}{4}italic_Î¸ = divide start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG. For every tj<tâ‰¤tj+1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—1t_{j}<t\leq t_{j+1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_t â‰¤ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we have

âˆ‘i=1t10â¢vâ¢Î»i1+Ïµ+2â¢(1+Ïµ)â¢logâ¡(2Î³j)+2â¢(1+Ïµ)â¢logâ¡(2Î¸)âˆ‘i=1tÎ»isuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘¡10ğ‘£superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–1italic-Ïµ21italic-Ïµ2subscriptğ›¾ğ‘—21italic-Ïµ2ğœƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘¡subscriptğœ†ğ‘–\displaystyle\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{t}10v\lambda_{i}^{1+\epsilon}+2(1+\epsilon)\log% \left(\frac{2}{\gamma_{j}}\right)+2(1+\epsilon)\log\left(\frac{2}{\theta}% \right)}{\sum_{i=1}^{t}\lambda_{i}}divide start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 10 italic_v italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 + italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 2 ( 1 + italic_Ïµ ) roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) + 2 ( 1 + italic_Ïµ ) roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î¸ end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG
=v11+Ïµâ¢10â¢tâ¢vâ¢Î›j1+Ïµ+2â¢(1+Ïµ)â¢logâ¡(2Î³j)+2â¢(1+Ïµ)â¢logâ¡(2Î¸)tâ¢Î›jâ‰¤absentsuperscriptğ‘£11italic-Ïµ10ğ‘¡ğ‘£superscriptsubscriptÎ›ğ‘—1italic-Ïµ21italic-Ïµ2subscriptğ›¾ğ‘—21italic-Ïµ2ğœƒğ‘¡subscriptÎ›ğ‘—absent\displaystyle=v^{\frac{1}{1+\epsilon}}\frac{10tv\Lambda_{j}^{1+\epsilon}+2(1+% \epsilon)\log\left(\frac{2}{\gamma_{j}}\right)+2(1+\epsilon)\log\left(\frac{2}% {\theta}\right)}{t\Lambda_{j}}\leq= italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 10 italic_t italic_v roman_Î› start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 + italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 2 ( 1 + italic_Ïµ ) roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) + 2 ( 1 + italic_Ïµ ) roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î¸ end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_t roman_Î› start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG â‰¤
â‰¤v11+Ïµâ¢(1+Ïµ)â¢10â¢v1+Ïµâ¢tâ¢Î›j1+Ïµ+4â¢logâ¡(2Î³j)tâ¢Î›jâ‰¤absentsuperscriptğ‘£11italic-Ïµ1italic-Ïµ10ğ‘£1italic-Ïµğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptÎ›ğ‘—1italic-Ïµ42subscriptğ›¾ğ‘—ğ‘¡subscriptÎ›ğ‘—absent\displaystyle\leq v^{\frac{1}{1+\epsilon}}(1+\epsilon)\frac{\frac{10v}{1+% \epsilon}t\Lambda_{j}^{1+\epsilon}+4\log\left(\frac{2}{\gamma_{j}}\right)}{t% \Lambda_{j}}\leqâ‰¤ italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 + italic_Ïµ ) divide start_ARG divide start_ARG 10 italic_v end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG italic_t roman_Î› start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 + italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 4 roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_t roman_Î› start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG â‰¤
â‰¤34â¢v11+Ïµâ¢(1+Ïµ)â¢(logâ¡(2Î³)+2â¢logâ¡(logâ¡(e2â¢t))t)Ïµ1+Ïµ.absent34superscriptğ‘£11italic-Ïµ1italic-Ïµsuperscript2ğ›¾2superscriptğ‘’2ğ‘¡ğ‘¡italic-Ïµ1italic-Ïµ\displaystyle\leq 34v^{\frac{1}{1+\epsilon}}(1+\epsilon)\left(\frac{\log\left(% \frac{2}{\gamma}\right)+2\log(\log(e^{2}t))}{t}\right)^{\frac{\epsilon}{1+% \epsilon}}.â‰¤ 34 italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 + italic_Ïµ ) ( divide start_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG ) + 2 roman_log ( roman_log ( italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t ) ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Noting that âˆ‘j=1âˆÎ³j<Î³superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1subscriptğ›¾ğ‘—ğ›¾\sum_{j=1}^{\infty}\gamma_{j}<\gammaâˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_Î³, this yields a tight bound over the width of the (1âˆ’Î³)1ğ›¾(1-\gamma)( 1 - italic_Î³ )-CS for Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼.

Step 5 (Good event characterization) As the width derived in the previous steps is not deterministic, we now characterize a favorable event in which such bound hold simultaneously for all (1âˆ’Î³)1ğ›¾(1-\gamma)( 1 - italic_Î³ )-CS. For any (1âˆ’Î³)1ğ›¾(1-\gamma)( 1 - italic_Î³ )-CS of length tğ‘¡titalic_t, we have that

Characterizing this event is necessary since Catoni-FCS-detector requires that CS widths well behave, i.e., they possess a deterministic upper bound.

We also introduce the event â„°tT={âˆ€iâˆˆ{t,â€¦,T},âˆ€tâ€²âˆˆ{i,â€¦,T}:Î¼âˆˆCâ¢Itâ€²(i)}superscriptsubscriptâ„°ğ‘¡ğ‘‡conditional-setformulae-sequencefor-allğ‘–ğ‘¡â€¦ğ‘‡for-allsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘–â€¦ğ‘‡ğœ‡ğ¶superscriptsubscriptğ¼superscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘–\mathcal{E}_{t}^{T}=\left\{\forall i\in\{t,\ldots,T\},\forall t^{\prime}\in\{i% ,\ldots,T\}:\mu\in CI_{t^{\prime}}^{(i)}\right\}caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { âˆ€ italic_i âˆˆ { italic_t , â€¦ , italic_T } , âˆ€ italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ { italic_i , â€¦ , italic_T } : italic_Î¼ âˆˆ italic_C italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }, that represents the scenario in which every (1âˆ’Î³)1ğ›¾(1-\gamma)( 1 - italic_Î³ )-CS starting from a timestamp greater or equal than tğ‘¡titalic_t never miscovers the true mean up to time Tğ‘‡Titalic_T. Step 6 (Verifying condition (16))

We obtain that it is satisfied for every tâ‰¥68â¢logâ¡(T1+ÏµÏµ)=nmâ¢iâ¢nğ‘¡68superscriptğ‘‡1italic-Ïµitalic-Ïµsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›t\geq 68\log\left(T^{\frac{1+\epsilon}{\epsilon}}\right)=n_{min}italic_t â‰¥ 68 roman_log ( italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is always true under the theoremâ€™s assumptions.

Step 7 (Bounding the detection delay) We are now ready to bound the detection delay of Catoni-FCS-detector after a change of magnitude Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ happened after tcsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘t_{c}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT samples. Note that we assume tcsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘t_{c}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to be large enough to satisfy Equation (16). To do so, we leverage the width of the (1âˆ’Î³)1ğ›¾(1-\gamma)( 1 - italic_Î³ )-CS that has just been derived. Suppose, without loss of generality, that a change point is detected after at most Tğ‘‡Titalic_T overall samples. Thus, we work under the events ğ’²1:Tsubscriptğ’²:1ğ‘‡\mathcal{W}_{1:T}caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, â„°1tcsuperscriptsubscriptâ„°1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘\mathcal{E}_{1}^{t_{c}}caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and â„°tcTsuperscriptsubscriptâ„°subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘‡\mathcal{E}_{t_{c}}^{T}caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, defined in Step 5, which hold simultaneously with probability at least 1âˆ’14T114ğ‘‡1-\frac{14}{T}1 - divide start_ARG 14 end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG, and guarantee that the CS widths are always properly bounded and the pre-change mean Î¼0subscriptğœ‡0\mu_{0}italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the post-change mean Î¼1subscriptğœ‡1\mu_{1}italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are never miscovered. By assumption, tcsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘t_{c}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is large enough to ensure

n1=minnâ‰¥1â¡{(logâ¡(logâ¡(n))n)Ïµ1+Ïµâ‰¤Î´~2}â¢andâ¢n2=minnâ‰¥1â¡{(logâ¡(T)n)Ïµ1+Ïµâ‰¤Î´~2},subscriptğ‘›1subscriptğ‘›1superscriptğ‘›ğ‘›italic-Ïµ1italic-Ïµ~ğ›¿2andsubscriptğ‘›2subscriptğ‘›1superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›italic-Ïµ1italic-Ïµ~ğ›¿2\displaystyle n_{1}=\min_{n\geq 1}\left\{\left(\frac{\log(\log(n))}{n}\right)^% {\frac{\epsilon}{1+\epsilon}}\leq\frac{\widetilde{\delta}}{2}\right\}~{}~{}~{}% \text{and}~{}~{}~{}n_{2}=\min_{n\geq 1}\left\{\left(\frac{\log(T)}{n}\right)^{% \frac{\epsilon}{1+\epsilon}}\leq\frac{\widetilde{\delta}}{2}\right\},italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n â‰¥ 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { ( divide start_ARG roman_log ( roman_log ( italic_n ) ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ divide start_ARG over~ start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG } and italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n â‰¥ 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { ( divide start_ARG roman_log ( italic_T ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ divide start_ARG over~ start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG } ,

We can thus upper bound them separately. It is trivial to observe that

As a consequence, we can rewrite:

Under the events defined above and that hold with probability at least 1âˆ’14T114ğ‘‡1-\frac{14}{T}1 - divide start_ARG 14 end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG, the detection delay is bounded as

(Ï„âˆ’tc)+superscriptğœsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘\displaystyle(\tau-t_{c})^{+}( italic_Ï„ - italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤(2â¢c~)1+ÏµÏµâ¢logâ¡(2â¢logâ¡(2â¢c~)â¢1+ÏµÏµ)+logâ¡(logâ¡(1Î´))+logâ¡(T)Î´1+ÏµÏµabsentsuperscript2~ğ‘1italic-Ïµitalic-Ïµ22~ğ‘1italic-Ïµitalic-Ïµ1ğ›¿ğ‘‡superscriptğ›¿1italic-Ïµitalic-Ïµ\displaystyle\leq(2\widetilde{c})^{\frac{1+\epsilon}{\epsilon}}\frac{\log\left% (2\log(2\widetilde{c})\frac{1+\epsilon}{\epsilon}\right)+\log\left(\log\left(% \frac{1}{{\delta}}\right)\right)+\log(T)}{{\delta}^{\frac{1+\epsilon}{\epsilon% }}}â‰¤ ( 2 over~ start_ARG italic_c end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG roman_log ( 2 roman_log ( 2 over~ start_ARG italic_c end_ARG ) divide start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG ) + roman_log ( roman_log ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ) ) + roman_log ( italic_T ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG

Step 8 (Bounding the probability of false alarm)

The bound on the probability of false alarm is a trivial consequence of the definition of event â„°1tcsuperscriptsubscriptâ„°1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘\mathcal{E}_{1}^{t_{c}}caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Under this event, it is impossible by construction for the detector to raise a false alarm, as all the CS always intersect at least on Î¼0subscriptğœ‡0\mu_{0}italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Thus, the probability of false alarm is bounded by â„™â¢((â„°1tc)C)â‰¤1Tâ„™superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptâ„°1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ¶1ğ‘‡\mathbb{P}\left((\mathcal{E}_{1}^{t_{c}})^{C}\right)\leq\frac{1}{T}blackboard_P ( ( caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰¤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG. âˆ

Lemma B.2.

Let ğ’¢Tâ‰”{âˆ€jâˆˆ[Î¥]:Ï„jâˆˆ{tc(j),â€¦,tc(j)+âŒˆLjâ¢KÎ·âŒ‰}â¢Â andÂ â¢tc(Î¥+1)>T}â‰”subscriptğ’¢ğ‘‡conditional-setfor-allğ‘—delimited-[]Î¥subscriptğœğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘—â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ¿ğ‘—ğ¾ğœ‚Â andÂ superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘Î¥1ğ‘‡\mathcal{G}_{T}\coloneqq\left\{\forall j\in[\Upsilon]:\tau_{j}\in\left\{t_{c}^% {(j)},\ldots,t_{c}^{(j)}+\left\lceil L_{j}\frac{K}{\eta}\right\rceil\right\}% \text{ and }t_{c}^{(\Upsilon+1)}>T\right\}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” { âˆ€ italic_j âˆˆ [ roman_Î¥ ] : italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + âŒˆ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î· end_ARG âŒ‰ } and italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_Î¥ + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > italic_T } be the event in which R-CPD-UCB restarts exactly Î¥Î¥\Upsilonroman_Î¥ times without false alarms and excessive delays. Then, we have â„™â¢(ğ’¢TC)â‰¤15â¢Kâ¢Î¥Tâ„™superscriptsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘‡ğ¶15ğ¾Î¥ğ‘‡\mathbb{P}\left(\mathcal{G}_{T}^{C}\right)\leq\frac{15K\Upsilon}{T}blackboard_P ( caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰¤ divide start_ARG 15 italic_K roman_Î¥ end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG.

Proof.

Note that, by construction of the algorithm, each action is sampled at least Ljsubscriptğ¿ğ‘—L_{j}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT times after âŒˆLjâ¢KÎ·âŒ‰subscriptğ¿ğ‘—ğ¾ğœ‚\left\lceil L_{j}\frac{K}{\eta}\right\rceilâŒˆ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î· end_ARG âŒ‰ timesteps have passed since the last detection point. Thanks to Assumption 4.7, the length of every epoch is at least 2â¢âŒˆLjâ¢KÎ·âŒ‰2subscriptğ¿ğ‘—ğ¾ğœ‚2\left\lceil L_{j}\frac{K}{\eta}\right\rceil2 âŒˆ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î· end_ARG âŒ‰.

Let â„’(j)â‰”{âˆ€mâ‰¤j:Ï„mâˆˆ{tc(m),â€¦,tc(m)+âŒˆLmâ¢KÎ·âŒ‰}}â‰”superscriptâ„’ğ‘—conditional-setfor-allğ‘šğ‘—subscriptğœğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘šâ€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘šsubscriptğ¿ğ‘šğ¾ğœ‚\mathcal{L}^{(j)}\coloneqq\left\{\forall m\leq j:\tau_{m}\in\left\{t_{c}^{(m)}% ,\ldots,t_{c}^{(m)}+\left\lceil L_{m}\frac{K}{\eta}\right\rceil\right\}\right\}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰” { âˆ€ italic_m â‰¤ italic_j : italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + âŒˆ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î· end_ARG âŒ‰ } } be the event in which all detections happened without false alarms and excessive delays up to the jğ‘—jitalic_j-th epoch. Then, by a union bound and by Proposition 4.2, we have:

â„™â¢(ğ’¢TC)â„™superscriptsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘‡ğ¶\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\left(\mathcal{G}_{T}^{C}\right)blackboard_P ( caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰¤âˆ‘j=1Î¥+1â„™â¢(Ï„jâ‰¤tc(j)âˆ£â„’(jâˆ’1))+âˆ‘j=1Î¥â„™â¢(Ï„jâ‰¥tc(j)+âŒˆLjâ¢KÎ·âŒ‰âˆ£â„’(jâˆ’1))absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1Î¥1â„™subscriptğœğ‘—conditionalsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘—superscriptâ„’ğ‘—1superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1Î¥â„™subscriptğœğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘—conditionalsubscriptğ¿ğ‘—ğ¾ğœ‚superscriptâ„’ğ‘—1\displaystyle\leq\sum_{j=1}^{\Upsilon+1}\mathbb{P}\left(\tau_{j}\leq t_{c}^{(j% )}\mid\mathcal{L}^{(j-1)}\right)+\sum_{j=1}^{\Upsilon}\mathbb{P}\left(\tau_{j}% \geq t_{c}^{(j)}+\left\lceil L_{j}\frac{K}{\eta}\right\rceil\mid\mathcal{L}^{(% j-1)}\right)â‰¤ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¥ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P ( italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ£ caligraphic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P ( italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + âŒˆ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î· end_ARG âŒ‰ âˆ£ caligraphic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )
â‰¤Kâ¢(Î¥+1)T+14â¢Kâ¢Î¥Tâ‰¤15â¢Kâ¢Î¥T.absentğ¾Î¥1ğ‘‡14ğ¾Î¥ğ‘‡15ğ¾Î¥ğ‘‡\displaystyle\leq\frac{K(\Upsilon+1)}{T}+\frac{14K\Upsilon}{T}\leq\frac{15K% \Upsilon}{T}.â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_K ( roman_Î¥ + 1 ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG + divide start_ARG 14 italic_K roman_Î¥ end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG â‰¤ divide start_ARG 15 italic_K roman_Î¥ end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG .

âˆ

See 4.8

Proof.

Let ğ’¢Tâ‰”{âˆ€jâˆˆ[Î¥]:Ï„jâˆˆ{tc(j),â€¦,tc(j)+âŒˆLjâ¢KÎ·âŒ‰}â¢Â andÂ â¢tc(Î¥+1)>T}â‰”subscriptğ’¢ğ‘‡conditional-setfor-allğ‘—delimited-[]Î¥subscriptğœğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘—â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ¿ğ‘—ğ¾ğœ‚Â andÂ superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘Î¥1ğ‘‡\mathcal{G}_{T}\coloneqq\left\{\forall j\in[\Upsilon]:\tau_{j}\in\left\{t_{c}^% {(j)},\ldots,t_{c}^{(j)}+\left\lceil L_{j}\frac{K}{\eta}\right\rceil\right\}% \text{ and }t_{c}^{(\Upsilon+1)}>T\right\}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” { âˆ€ italic_j âˆˆ [ roman_Î¥ ] : italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + âŒˆ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î· end_ARG âŒ‰ } and italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_Î¥ + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > italic_T } be the event in which R-CPD-UCB restarts exactly Î¥Î¥\Upsilonroman_Î¥ times without false alarms and excessive delays.

We start by decomposing the regret in the following way:

ğ”¼â¢[RÏ€R-CPD-UCBâ¢(T)]ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘…superscriptğœ‹R-CPD-UCBğ‘‡\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[R^{\pi^{\text{R-CPD-UCB\@}}}(T)]blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT R-CPD-UCB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) ] â‰¤ğ”¼â¢[RÏ€R-CPD-UCBâ¢(T)âˆ£ğ’¢T]+ğ”¼â¢[RÏ€R-CPD-UCBâ¢(T)âˆ£ğ’¢TC]â¢â„™â¢(ğ’¢TC)absentğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptğ‘…superscriptğœ‹R-CPD-UCBğ‘‡subscriptğ’¢ğ‘‡ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptğ‘…superscriptğœ‹R-CPD-UCBğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘‡ğ¶â„™superscriptsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘‡ğ¶\displaystyle\leq\mathbb{E}[R^{\pi^{\text{R-CPD-UCB\@}}}(T)\mid\mathcal{G}_{T}% ]+\mathbb{E}[R^{\pi^{\text{R-CPD-UCB\@}}}(T)\mid\mathcal{G}_{T}^{C}]\mathbb{P}% \left(\mathcal{G}_{T}^{C}\right)â‰¤ blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT R-CPD-UCB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) âˆ£ caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] + blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT R-CPD-UCB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) âˆ£ caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] blackboard_P ( caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )
â‰¤ğ”¼â¢[RÏ€R-CPD-UCBâ¢(T)âˆ£ğ’¢T]+15â¢Kâ¢Î¥,absentğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptğ‘…superscriptğœ‹R-CPD-UCBğ‘‡subscriptğ’¢ğ‘‡15ğ¾Î¥\displaystyle\leq\mathbb{E}[R^{\pi^{\text{R-CPD-UCB\@}}}(T)\mid\mathcal{G}_{T}% ]+15K\Upsilon,â‰¤ blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT R-CPD-UCB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) âˆ£ caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] + 15 italic_K roman_Î¥ ,

where the second inequality follows from Lemma B.2. We can now focus on bounding the first addendum. We decompose it as follows:

ğ”¼â¢[RÏ€R-CPD-UCBâ¢(T)âˆ£ğ’¢T]ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptğ‘…superscriptğœ‹R-CPD-UCBğ‘‡subscriptğ’¢ğ‘‡\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[R^{\pi^{\text{R-CPD-UCB\@}}}(T)\mid\mathcal{G}_{T}]blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT R-CPD-UCB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) âˆ£ caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] =ğ”¼â¢[RÏ€R-CPD-UCBâ¢(T)âˆ’RÏ€R-CPD-UCBâ¢(tc(1))âˆ£ğ’¢T]+ğ”¼â¢[RÏ€R-CPD-UCBâ¢(tc(1))âˆ£ğ’¢T]absentğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘…superscriptğœ‹R-CPD-UCBğ‘‡conditionalsuperscriptğ‘…superscriptğœ‹R-CPD-UCBsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘1subscriptğ’¢ğ‘‡ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptğ‘…superscriptğœ‹R-CPD-UCBsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘1subscriptğ’¢ğ‘‡\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}[R^{\pi^{\text{R-CPD-UCB\@}}}(T)-R^{\pi^{\text{R-CPD-% UCB\@}}}(t_{c}^{(1)})\mid\mathcal{G}_{T}]+\mathbb{E}[R^{\pi^{\text{R-CPD-UCB\@% }}}(t_{c}^{(1)})\mid\mathcal{G}_{T}]= blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT R-CPD-UCB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) - italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT R-CPD-UCB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆ£ caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] + blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT R-CPD-UCB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆ£ caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]
â‰¤ğ”¼â¢[RÏ€R-CPD-UCBâ¢(T)âˆ’RÏ€R-CPD-UCBâ¢(tc(1))âˆ£ğ’¢T]+Î·â¢tc(1)â¢Î”mâ¢aâ¢x(1)+ğ”¼â¢[RÏ€sâ¢(tc(1))],absentğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘…superscriptğœ‹R-CPD-UCBğ‘‡conditionalsuperscriptğ‘…superscriptğœ‹R-CPD-UCBsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘1subscriptğ’¢ğ‘‡ğœ‚superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘1superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥1ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘…subscriptğœ‹ğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘1\displaystyle\leq\mathbb{E}[R^{\pi^{\text{R-CPD-UCB\@}}}(T)-R^{\pi^{\text{R-% CPD-UCB\@}}}(t_{c}^{(1)})\mid\mathcal{G}_{T}]+\eta t_{c}^{(1)}\Delta_{max}^{(1% )}+\mathbb{E}[R^{\pi_{s}}(t_{c}^{(1)})],â‰¤ blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT R-CPD-UCB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) - italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT R-CPD-UCB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆ£ caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] + italic_Î· italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] ,

where the inequality follows by upper bounding the contribution to the regret given by the forced exploration in the first tc(1)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘1t_{c}^{(1)}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT rounds, the remaining term is the expected regret accrued by the policy Ï€ssubscriptğœ‹ğ‘ \pi_{s}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT up to tc(1)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘1t_{c}^{(1)}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We prosecute by bounding the first addendum as follows:

ğ”¼â¢[RÏ€R-CPD-UCBâ¢(T)âˆ’RÏ€R-CPD-UCBâ¢(tc(1))âˆ£ğ’¢T]ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘…superscriptğœ‹R-CPD-UCBğ‘‡conditionalsuperscriptğ‘…superscriptğœ‹R-CPD-UCBsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘1subscriptğ’¢ğ‘‡\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[R^{\pi^{\text{R-CPD-UCB\@}}}(T)-R^{\pi^{\text{R-CPD-% UCB\@}}}(t_{c}^{(1)})\mid\mathcal{G}_{T}]blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT R-CPD-UCB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) - italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT R-CPD-UCB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆ£ caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] =ğ”¼â¢[RÏ€R-CPD-UCBâ¢(T)âˆ’RÏ€R-CPD-UCBâ¢(Ï„1)âˆ£ğ’¢T]+absentlimit-fromğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘…superscriptğœ‹R-CPD-UCBğ‘‡conditionalsuperscriptğ‘…superscriptğœ‹R-CPD-UCBsubscriptğœ1subscriptğ’¢ğ‘‡\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}[R^{\pi^{\text{R-CPD-UCB\@}}}(T)-R^{\pi^{\text{R-CPD-% UCB\@}}}(\tau_{1})\mid\mathcal{G}_{T}]+= blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT R-CPD-UCB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) - italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT R-CPD-UCB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ£ caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] +
+ğ”¼â¢[RÏ€R-CPD-UCBâ¢(Ï„1)âˆ’RÏ€R-CPD-UCBâ¢(tc(1))âˆ£ğ’¢T]ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘…superscriptğœ‹R-CPD-UCBsubscriptğœ1conditionalsuperscriptğ‘…superscriptğœ‹R-CPD-UCBsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘1subscriptğ’¢ğ‘‡\displaystyle~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}+\mathbb{E}[R^{\pi^{\text{R-CPD-UCB\@}}}(\tau_{1})% -R^{\pi^{\text{R-CPD-UCB\@}}}(t_{c}^{(1)})\mid\mathcal{G}_{T}]+ blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT R-CPD-UCB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT R-CPD-UCB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆ£ caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]
â‰¤ğ”¼2â¢[RÏ€R-CPD-UCBâ¢(Tâˆ’Ï„1)âˆ£ğ’¢T]+ğ”¼â¢[(Ï„1âˆ’tc(1))âˆ£ğ’¢T]â¢Î”mâ¢aâ¢x(1),absentsubscriptğ”¼2delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptğ‘…superscriptğœ‹R-CPD-UCBğ‘‡subscriptğœ1subscriptğ’¢ğ‘‡ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsubscriptğœ1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘1subscriptğ’¢ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥1\displaystyle\leq\mathbb{E}_{2}[R^{\pi^{\text{R-CPD-UCB\@}}}(T-\tau_{1})\mid% \mathcal{G}_{T}]+\mathbb{E}[(\tau_{1}-t_{c}^{(1)})\mid\mathcal{G}_{T}]\Delta_{% max}^{(1)},â‰¤ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT R-CPD-UCB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T - italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ£ caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] + blackboard_E [ ( italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆ£ caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where ğ”¼2subscriptğ”¼2\mathbb{E}_{2}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the expectation according to an environment starting from the second segment. Putting all together, we can write

ğ”¼â¢[RÏ€R-CPD-UCBâ¢(T)âˆ£ğ’¢T]â‰¤ğ”¼2â¢[RÏ€R-CPD-UCBâ¢(Tâˆ’Ï„1)âˆ£ğ’¢T]+ğ”¼â¢[(Ï„1âˆ’tc(1))âˆ£ğ’¢T]â¢Î”mâ¢aâ¢x(1)+Î·â¢tc(1)â¢Î”mâ¢aâ¢x(1)+ğ”¼â¢[RÏ€sâ¢(tc(1))],ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptğ‘…superscriptğœ‹R-CPD-UCBğ‘‡subscriptğ’¢ğ‘‡subscriptğ”¼2delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptğ‘…superscriptğœ‹R-CPD-UCBğ‘‡subscriptğœ1subscriptğ’¢ğ‘‡ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsubscriptğœ1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘1subscriptğ’¢ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥1ğœ‚superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘1superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥1ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘…subscriptğœ‹ğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘1\mathbb{E}[R^{\pi^{\text{R-CPD-UCB\@}}}(T)\mid\mathcal{G}_{T}]\leq\mathbb{E}_{% 2}[R^{\pi^{\text{R-CPD-UCB\@}}}(T-\tau_{1})\mid\mathcal{G}_{T}]+\mathbb{E}[(% \tau_{1}-t_{c}^{(1)})\mid\mathcal{G}_{T}]\Delta_{max}^{(1)}+\eta t_{c}^{(1)}% \Delta_{max}^{(1)}+\mathbb{E}[R^{\pi_{s}}(t_{c}^{(1)})],blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT typewriter_R-CPD-UCB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) âˆ£ caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] â‰¤ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT typewriter_R-CPD-UCB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T - italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ£ caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] + blackboard_E [ ( italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆ£ caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Î· italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] ,

which yields, by a recursive application:

ğ”¼â¢[RÏ€R-CPD-UCBâ¢(T)âˆ£ğ’¢T]ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptğ‘…superscriptğœ‹R-CPD-UCBğ‘‡subscriptğ’¢ğ‘‡\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[R^{\pi^{\text{R-CPD-UCB\@}}}(T)\mid\mathcal{G}_{T}]blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT R-CPD-UCB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) âˆ£ caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] â‰¤âˆ‘j=1Î¥ğ”¼â¢[(Ï„jâˆ’tc(j))âˆ£ğ’¢T]â¢Î”mâ¢aâ¢x(1)+âˆ‘j=1Î¥ğ”¼â¢[RÏ€sâ¢(|Ej|)]+Î·â¢Tâ¢Î”mâ¢aâ¢x(1)absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1Î¥ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsubscriptğœğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ’¢ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥1superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1Î¥ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘…subscriptğœ‹ğ‘ subscriptğ¸ğ‘—ğœ‚ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥1\displaystyle\leq\sum_{j=1}^{\Upsilon}\mathbb{E}[(\tau_{j}-t_{c}^{(j)})\mid% \mathcal{G}_{T}]\Delta_{max}^{(1)}+\sum_{j=1}^{\Upsilon}\mathbb{E}[R^{\pi_{s}}% (|E_{j}|)]+\eta T\Delta_{max}^{(1)}â‰¤ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ ( italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆ£ caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( | italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ) ] + italic_Î· italic_T roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
â‰¤âˆ‘j=1Î¥âŒˆLjâ¢KÎ·âŒ‰â¢Î”mâ¢aâ¢x(1)+âˆ‘j=1Î¥ğ”¼â¢[RÏ€sâ¢(|Ej|)]+Î·â¢Tâ¢Î”mâ¢aâ¢x(1),absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1Î¥subscriptğ¿ğ‘—ğ¾ğœ‚superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥1superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1Î¥ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘…subscriptğœ‹ğ‘ subscriptğ¸ğ‘—ğœ‚ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥1\displaystyle\leq\sum_{j=1}^{\Upsilon}\left\lceil L_{j}\frac{K}{\eta}\right% \rceil\Delta_{max}^{(1)}+\sum_{j=1}^{\Upsilon}\mathbb{E}[R^{\pi_{s}}(|E_{j}|)]% +\eta T\Delta_{max}^{(1)},â‰¤ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŒˆ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î· end_ARG âŒ‰ roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( | italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ) ] + italic_Î· italic_T roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where the second inequality follows from the definition of ğ’¢Tsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘‡\mathcal{G}_{T}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The proof is concluded by substituting Ljsubscriptğ¿ğ‘—L_{j}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with its definition. âˆ

See 4.10

Proof.

The proof of this theorem trivially follows from plugging the regret bounds of Robust UCB with MoM estimator (Theorem 3 and Proposition 1 of [7]). Equation (9) necessitates an additional step using Jensen Inequality:

âˆ‘j=1Î¥KÏµ1+Ïµâ¢(vâ¢T)11+Ïµâ‰¤Î¥â¢(K)Ïµ1+Ïµâ¢(vâ¢TÎ¥)11+Ïµ=(Î¥â¢K)Ïµ1+Ïµâ¢(vâ¢T)11+Ïµ.superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1Î¥superscriptğ¾italic-Ïµ1italic-Ïµsuperscriptğ‘£ğ‘‡11italic-ÏµÎ¥superscriptğ¾italic-Ïµ1italic-Ïµsuperscriptğ‘£ğ‘‡Î¥11italic-ÏµsuperscriptÎ¥ğ¾italic-Ïµ1italic-Ïµsuperscriptğ‘£ğ‘‡11italic-Ïµ\sum_{j=1}^{\Upsilon}K^{\frac{\epsilon}{1+\epsilon}}(vT)^{\frac{1}{1+\epsilon}% }\leq\Upsilon(K)^{\frac{\epsilon}{1+\epsilon}}\left(\frac{vT}{\Upsilon}\right)% ^{\frac{1}{1+\epsilon}}=(\Upsilon K)^{\frac{\epsilon}{1+\epsilon}}(vT)^{\frac{% 1}{1+\epsilon}}.âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î¥ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_v italic_T ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ roman_Î¥ ( italic_K ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG italic_v italic_T end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î¥ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( roman_Î¥ italic_K ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_v italic_T ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Proof.

First, note that the proof of Theorem 4.8 can be conducted in the exact same way by substituting Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· with the sequence {Î·j}jâˆˆ[Î¥+1]subscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘—ğ‘—delimited-[]Î¥1\{\eta_{j}\}_{j\in[\Upsilon+1]}{ italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j âˆˆ [ roman_Î¥ + 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.
