Appendix C Additional Numerical Evaluations

In this appendix, we provide additional details on the experimental evaluation of Section 5 and additional experimental campaigns in synthetic environments.

C.1 Detection Delay Analysis

We evaluate how reactive is Catoni-FCS-detector to changes of data-generating distribution, and comparing it repeated-FCS-detector with Empirical Bernstein CSs from [26], Section 2.2, which is suited for distributions with finite variance. We consider two distribution-shift scenarios: Gaussian distributions with Ïƒ=1ğœ1\sigma=1italic_Ïƒ = 1 and Laplace distributions with scale equal to 1111. The change happens after tc=400subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘400t_{c}=400italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 400 steps, and the total horizon is T=1000ğ‘‡1000T=1000italic_T = 1000. The magnitude of change is Î´=1ğ›¿1\delta=1italic_Î´ = 1. In Figure 4, we report the distribution of the detection delay of both algorithm over 20202020 trials. We can see how, in general, Catoni-FCS-detector has a smaller detection delay w.r.t. repeated-FCS-detector. Moreover, no false alarm is raised along the 20202020 trials.

C.2 Regret Minimization in Highly Non-Stationary Environments

In this section, we evaluate how R-CPD-UCB behaves in highly dynamic scenarios where change-points are close.
Setting We confront R-CPD-UCB with two of the most popular algorithms from the literature, Monitored UCB [8] and Sliding Window UCB [11]. We consider two PS MABs: Gaussian rewards with Ïƒ=1ğœ1\sigma=1italic_Ïƒ = 1 and Pareto rewards with Ïµ<12italic-Ïµ12\epsilon<\frac{1}{2}italic_Ïµ < divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG and v<3ğ‘£3v<3italic_v < 3. In both MABs, we have K=3ğ¾3K=3italic_K = 3, T=1500ğ‘‡1500T=1500italic_T = 1500 and Î¥=6Î¥6\Upsilon=6roman_Î¥ = 6. Also, we have Î´mâ¢iâ¢n=0subscriptğ›¿ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›0\delta_{min}=0italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, i.e., and some actions may not change their means after a change-point. However, at least one arm has its mean change, and the optimal action changes at least 4444 times. Interestingly, these instances violate Assumption 4.7. We use Ïƒ=1ğœ1\sigma=1italic_Ïƒ = 1 and the means reported in Table 1(a) for the Gaussian scenario. The optimal actions change 4444 times. For the Pareto scenario, we use Ïµ=12italic-Ïµ12\epsilon=\frac{1}{2}italic_Ïµ = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG, v=3ğ‘£3v=3italic_v = 3, and the means reported in Table 1(b). The optimal actions change 4444 times. In Figure 7 we report the means of every action in every epoch.

Results In Figure 5, we report the cumulative regrets suffered by the considered algorithms. For each instance and algorithm, we performed 20202020 trials and reported the average cumulative regrets with their aleatoric uncertainties. R-CPD-UCB achieves, in both instances, a smaller cumulative regret than competitors. Moreover, it shows a smaller uncertainty and more stable performances across the trials, especially when rewards have infinite variance (Figure 5(b)). Interestingly, R-CPD-UCB can outperform both Monitored UCB and Sliding Window UCB even when the rewards are Gaussian. This is probably because the change-points are frequent and very close. Robust mean estimation using median-of-means stabilizes the algorithmâ€™s behavior in data-scarce regimes. Finally, we remark that Assumption 4.7 is violated by these two instances; however, R-CPD-UCB performs well (and so is Monitored UCB, which relies on a similar hypothesis). This phenomenon was already observed in [8], and shows how Assumption 4.7 is, in practice, is not very limiting.

C.3 Sensibility to Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´

In this section, we study the sensibility of R-CPD-UCB to different magnitudes of changes.

Setting

We consider four HTPS MABs with Pareto rewards (Ïµ<1italic-Ïµ1\epsilon<1italic_Ïµ < 1, v=1ğ‘£1v=1italic_v = 1), K=3ğ¾3K=3italic_K = 3, T=500ğ‘‡500T=500italic_T = 500, and Î¥=1Î¥1\Upsilon=1roman_Î¥ = 1. The starting means are Î¼1=1subscriptğœ‡11\mu_{1}=1italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1, Î¼2=0.8subscriptğœ‡20.8\mu_{2}=0.8italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.8 and Î¼2=0.5subscriptğœ‡20.5\mu_{2}=0.5italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.5, and a change occurs at tc=200subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘200t_{c}=200italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 200. We let Î´1=1subscriptğ›¿11\delta_{1}=1italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1, Î´3=0subscriptğ›¿30\delta_{3}=0italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 (thus, Î´mâ¢iâ¢n=0subscriptğ›¿ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›0\delta_{min}=0italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0) and Î´2âˆˆ{1,2,5,10}subscriptğ›¿212510\delta_{2}\in\{1,2,5,10\}italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { 1 , 2 , 5 , 10 }, respectively. In the first PS MAB, the first action remains optimal from the start to the end of the trial; in the others, the second action becomes optimal after the change. In Figure 8, we report the means of every action in every epoch for the four HTPS MABs.

Results

In Figure 9, we report the cumulative regrets suffered by R-CPD-UCB in the four HTPS MABs. For each instance, we performed 20202020 trials and reported the average cumulative regret (on the right), together with its standard deviation. Moreover, the dashed vertical lines indicate the average detection time and their standard deviations. As the four instances differ in terms of magnitude (e.g., in the first instance, the maximum mean is 2222, and in the fourth is 10.810.810.810.8), we also reported the rescaled cumulative regrets (on the left). R-CPD-UCB can detect the change with a reasonable delay, and all cumulative regrets show sublinear growth. As Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ grows, the cumulative regret is larger, but the detection delay decreases. Intuitively, a larger change yields a larger regret but is also easier to detect. From the rescaled cumulative regrets, we can observe how a large Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ w.r.t. to the mean does not deteriorate the performance of R-CPD-UCB.

C.4 Stationary Environments

In this section, we study the empirical behavior of R-CPD-UCB in stationary HT MABs.

Setting

We consider four HT MABs with Pareto rewards (Ïµ<1italic-Ïµ1\epsilon<1italic_Ïµ < 1, v=1ğ‘£1v=1italic_v = 1), K=3ğ¾3K=3italic_K = 3, T=300ğ‘‡300T=300italic_T = 300, and Î¥=0Î¥0\Upsilon=0roman_Î¥ = 0. We compare R-CPD-UCB with two gold standards from the literature: Robust UCB [7] and MR-APE [19].

Results

We remark that, in a stationary environment, the behavior of R-CPD-UCB diverges from the one of Robust UCB in only two cases: (i) when there is a false detection (happens with probability smaller than Tâˆ’1superscriptğ‘‡1T^{-1}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) and (ii) R-CPD-UCB performs a forced exploration (once every ğ’ªâ¢(Tâˆ’12)ğ’ªsuperscriptğ‘‡12\mathcal{O}(T^{-\frac{1}{2}})caligraphic_O ( italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) rounds). In both cases, the contribution to the regret is small compared to the dominant term, adding a constant factor at most. In Figure 10, we report the cumulative regrets suffered by the algorithms in the four HT MABs. For each instance, we performed 20202020 trials and reported the average cumulative regret, together with its standard deviation. R-CPD-UCB raises only one false alarm in one trial of the fourth instance, and the average cumulative regret is thus slightly larger than the one Robust UCB, which is suited for the stationary setting. R-CPD-UCB suffers cumulative regrets comparable to the ones of algorithms suited for the stationary case. All cumulative regrets show sublinear growth.

Appendix D Computational Complexity of Robust-CPD-UCB

In this section, we characterize the computational complexity of R-CPD-UCB and provide a simple modification to the algorithm that allows for quicker computation while keeping similar theoretical guarantees. For the sake of traceability, we assume that all means belong to the set [âˆ’M,M]ğ‘€ğ‘€[-M,M][ - italic_M , italic_M ]. We start by upper bounding the computational complexity of R-CPD-UCB.

Proposition D.1.

Let M~=ğ’ª(M+v11+Ïµlog(T)Ïµ1+Ïµ)\widetilde{M}=\mathcal{O}\left(M+v^{\frac{1}{1+\epsilon}}\log(T)^{\frac{% \epsilon}{1+\epsilon}}\right)over~ start_ARG italic_M end_ARG = caligraphic_O ( italic_M + italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( italic_T ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Let Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ be the machine tolerance. Then, R-CPD-UCB takes at most ğ’ªâ¢(Kâ¢T4â¢log2â¡(M~Î¾))ğ’ªğ¾superscriptğ‘‡4subscript2~ğ‘€ğœ‰\mathcal{O}\left(KT^{4}\log_{2}\left(\frac{\widetilde{M}}{\xi}\right)\right)caligraphic_O ( italic_K italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG over~ start_ARG italic_M end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î¾ end_ARG ) ) steps with probability at least 1âˆ’1T11ğ‘‡1-\frac{1}{T}1 - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG.

Proof.

Using the bisection method with a tolerance of Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾, and searching in the interval [âˆ’M~,M~]~ğ‘€~ğ‘€[-\widetilde{M},\widetilde{M}][ - over~ start_ARG italic_M end_ARG , over~ start_ARG italic_M end_ARG ], we can solve the two root-finding problems implied by Equation (5) in at most ğ’ªâ¢(Tâ¢log2â¡(M~Î¾))ğ’ªğ‘‡subscript2~ğ‘€ğœ‰\mathcal{O}\left(T\log_{2}\left(\frac{\widetilde{M}}{\xi}\right)\right)caligraphic_O ( italic_T roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG over~ start_ARG italic_M end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î¾ end_ARG ) ). Note that, by Theorem 3.2 from [6], the solution lies in the search interval with probability at least Î©â¢(1âˆ’1T)Î©11ğ‘‡\Omega\left(1-\frac{1}{T}\right)roman_Î© ( 1 - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ). Then, we observe that R-CPD-UCB, at each round tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T]italic_t âˆˆ [ italic_T ], for every action iâˆˆ[K]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ¾i\in[K]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_K ], runs a step of the Catoni-FCS-detector which computes tğ‘¡titalic_t CS of lengths t,tâˆ’1,â€¦,2,1ğ‘¡ğ‘¡1â€¦21t,t-1,\ldots,2,1italic_t , italic_t - 1 , â€¦ , 2 , 1. Computing a CS of length tâ€²â‰¤Tsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘‡t^{\prime}\leq Titalic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_T requires to compute tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT CIs, which requires ğ’ªâ¢(tâ€²â¢log2â¡(M~Î¾))ğ’ªsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²subscript2~ğ‘€ğœ‰\mathcal{O}\left(t^{\prime}\log_{2}\left(\frac{\widetilde{M}}{\xi}\right)\right)caligraphic_O ( italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG over~ start_ARG italic_M end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î¾ end_ARG ) ) steps at most for each of them. Note that a solution always exists as the number of samples is always greater than nmâ¢iâ¢nsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›n_{min}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT when the CPD routine is executed. The result follows by upper bounding t,tâ€²â‰¤Tğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘‡t,t^{\prime}\leq Titalic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_T. âˆ

Proposition D.1 states that the computational complexity of R-CPD-UCB is polynomial in Tğ‘‡Titalic_T.
